\u00b1 115\u00a0</td><td>14.1 \u00b1 1.6\u00a0</td><td>\u22120.89 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>Yes\u00a0</td><td>3\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 1703\u00a0</td><td>8.66\u00a0</td><td>N/A\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-t5_note210\"></span><div content-id=\"t5_note210\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> X-ray luminosity in the 0.1\u20132.4 keV band from <em>ROSAT</em> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 1998</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00f6hringer et al. 2004</a>). <sup><em>b</em></sup><em>Chandra</em> observation identifier. <sup><em>c</em></sup>Measured between 0.15 and 0.2<em>r</em><sub>500</sub> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. 2009b</a>). <sup><em>d</em></sup>Logarithmic slope of the gas density profile at 0.04<em>r</em><sub>500</sub> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vikhlinin et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b68\" data-open=\"b68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson &amp; Ponman 2010</a>). <sup><em>e</em></sup>X-ray centroid/BCG offset from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. (2009a)</a>. Errors are 1\u03c3.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/64680532\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680533 id=\"64680533\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3>3 STRONG-LENSING ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now describe the multiple-image galaxies used to constrain mass models of the 10 new strong-lensing clusters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.1</a>), and the methods used to construct the models themselves (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680535 id=\"64680535\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1>3.1 Multiple images and spectroscopic redshifts</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The multiple-image constraints used for each cluster are described below, and summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>, including their astrometry, photometry and available spectroscopic redshifts. The locations of the multiple images are also marked in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>. The naming convention for multiple images in a given cluster is the following: (1.1, 1.2, 1.3, \u2026) are individual images in system 1 (2.1, 2.2, 2.3, \u2026), in system 2 and so on.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680537 id=\"64680537\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-1>3.1.1 A 521</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The WFPC2 observations revealed a triple-image face-on spiral just 6 arcsec from the BCG, and containing many individual knots of star formation. The clear symmetry between these knots (marked A to E in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>) confirms a strong-lensing system of three images, which we measure to be at <em>z</em>= 1.034 from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission and UV absorption lines. We included the three brightest knots of each image as nine individual constraints for the mass modelling. The system was previously identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b48\" data-open=\"b48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maurogordato et al. (1996)</a> using Canada\u2013France\u2013Hawaii Telescope ground-based imaging. However, the poor angular resolution of their data prevented them from identifying it as strongly lensed, and subsequent spectroscopy was also inconclusive (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maurogordato et al. 2000</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680539 id=\"64680539\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-2>3.1.2 A 611</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify four systems, the first of which (1.1\u20131.5) clearly appears as five images of identical clumpy morphology, each of them composed of five individual knots (A to E) of star formation. We obtained a spectroscopic redshift for 1.2 and 1.3, showing identical features of a <em>z</em>= 2.06 galaxy. The locations of the radial counter-images (1.4 and 1.5) are confirmed by a preliminary mass model. The second system (2.1\u20132.3) appears as a giant arc to the north-east of the BCG, for which we derive <em>z</em>= 0.908 from strong [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission. This giant arc is clearly affected by the presence of cluster substructure, with significant changes of curvature close to individual galaxies. The third system (3.1\u20133.4) was identified thanks to the symmetry between 3.1 and 3.2. The mass model predicts counter images that we identify as 3.3 and 3.4. Finally, a very faint arc (4.1) serendipitously falling in one of the slits was confirmed at <em>z</em>= 2.54 with strong Ly\u03b1 emission. The mass model confirmed it is located on the <em>z</em>= 2.5 critical line, and predicts the counter image that we identify as 4.2.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680541 id=\"64680541\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-3>3.1.3 A 773</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify three multiple-image systems in this cluster. System 1 is a triple-image system with a clear symmetry between components 1.1 and 1.2. We derived a redshift <em>z</em>= 2.3 for both images and identify the counter-image 1.3 with help from the mass model. The second system (2.1 and 2.2) is a radial image and counter-image at <em>z</em>= 3.84 from strong Ly\u03b1 emission. Finally, we found a spectroscopic redshift <em>z</em>= 1.0 for the third system (3.1 and 3.2) curving around one of the cluster galaxies.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680543 id=\"64680543\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-4>3.1.4 A 868</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A giant arc containing three bright images (1.1\u20131.3) is clearly found around the second brightest galaxy to the north-east of the BCG. We derive its redshift at <em>z</em>= 0.551 from the combination of [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emissions. The curvature of this arc suggests it is strongly affected by a secondary mass component, as well as the main component centred on the BCG.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680545 id=\"64680545\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-5>3.1.5 Z2701</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We identify a first system (1.1 to 1.3) as three compact images \u223c10 arcsec from the BCG, confirmed to be at <em>z</em>= 1.163. A second system is formed by two faint symmetric arcs (2.1 and 2.2), for which the mass model predicts a counter-image identified as 2.3.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680547 id=\"64680547\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-6>3.1.6 A 1413</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The two-filter ACS data enable four multiple-image galaxies to be identified from their colours and morphologies, three of them having spectroscopic redshifts between <em>z</em>= 1.17 and 2.77, from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] or Ly\u03b1 in emission. System 1 is a bright fold arc to the north, where we identify two bright knots as 1.1 and 1.2. The three other systems are triple image with clear mirror symmetry.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680549 id=\"64680549\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-7>3.1.7 A 1835</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Several studies have previously identified strongly-lensed arcs in this cluster (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b71\" data-open=\"b71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schmidt, Allen &amp; Fabian 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b67\" data-open=\"b67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. 2005</a>; Sm05), however, to date spectroscopic redshifts have not been measured for any of these background galaxies, thereby limiting the precision of previous attempts to model the mass distribution in this cluster. We report redshift measurements for two systems: one of them is a triple system (labelled 5) discovered during a narrow-band search for Ly\u03b1 emitters at <em>z</em>= 2.5 (Dannerbauer et al., in preparation), as two objects with similar morphologies and strong Ly\u03b1 emission. A radial counter image (5.3) is predicted close to the BCG. The second is a pair of merging images (system 7) measured at <em>z</em>= 2.07, for which we identify two counter images 7.2 and 7.3. A fourth image 7.4 is predicted very close to the BCG but the light of the BCG prevents a reliable identification. Finally, we checked that the submillimetre sources J1/J2 discussed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b75\" data-open=\"b75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail, Smith &amp; Ivison (2005)</a> at <em>z</em>= 2.56 are indeed predicted by the mass model to be single image.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680551 id=\"64680551\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-8>3.1.8 A 2204</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The redshift of a radial arc (1.1 and 1.2) was measured to be <em>z</em>= 1.0 from strong [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission during an Integral Field Unit (IFU) observation of the central galaxy with the Visible Multi Object Spectrograph (VIMOS) instrument (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b90\" data-open=\"b90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wilman, Edge &amp; Swinbank 2006</a>). We confirm this redshift independently, and find the same redshift for 1.3, which our mass model predicted to be the counter image.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680553 id=\"64680553\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-9>3.1.9 RX J1720</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This cluster is constrained by a giant arc (1.1 and 1.2) curving around the BCG, with a spectroscopic redshift <em>z</em>= 2.136 from the magnesium doublet. We identify two counter images (1.3 and 1.4) with help from the mass model.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680555 id=\"64680555\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-1-10>3.1.10 RX J2129</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Two compact sources with mirror symmetry (1.1 and 1.2) have been identified <em>z</em>= 1.965 from UV absorption lines, and the location of the counter image 1.3 was identified with the mass model.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680557 id=\"64680557\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2>3.2 Cluster mass models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have used <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b37\" data-open=\"b37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib 1993</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>) to reconstruct the distribution of mass in the cluster cores, which is described as a superposition of analytic mass components that account for both cluster- and galaxy-scale mass, following Sm05. We use all the multiple-image systems described in the previous section and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a> as model constraints, using spectroscopic redshifts whenever available. The main differences between these models and those of Sm05 are that unknown multiple-image redshifts are free parameters in the models, and two different parametrizations are used for the smooth cluster-scale mass components (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2.1</a>), and parameter space is explored using the Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampler that is now available within <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2.4</a>). In common with Sm05 and other studies of strong-lensing clusters by our group (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b77\" data-open=\"b77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2001</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b78\" data-open=\"b78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b44\" data-open=\"b44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2009</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009a</a>), the mass modelling is an iterative process, as we first produce a rudimentary mass model, based on the most reliable constraints, and then gradually incorporate additional constraints.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680559 id=\"64680559\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2-1>3.2.1 Cluster-scale mass components</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The mass distribution of cluster cores within the strong-lensing region is generally well described by a smooth elliptical profile centred near the BCG. As a starting point in our analysis, we try to reproduce the strong lensing constraints using a double pseudo-isothermal elliptical (dPIE) mass distribution [also known as a smoothly truncated pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (PIEMD); <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. 2007</a>]. The dPIE profile, which was also used in Sm05, is characterized by its central position, position angle and ellipticity, the central velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>0</sub> and two characteristic radii: a core radius <em>r</em><sub>core</sub> and a cut radius <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>. In an (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) coordinate system oriented along the angle \u03b8 of the ellipse, the surface mass density takes the form <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m1\" content-id=\"m1\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0404-0325-m1.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-m1.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=mV2SAVm30Yrp2ZkepU-dav9DarD08qU1djHTb20ZpbWQvHjRx-odd4uqMZ7yeI49o1sEjkCv6kc0rkPaaESWZxWD4RDhgL63ms0Fsq3FGXLh0cOdIPCEjp5edY8yttnF2U6cnYfUzgsGq-B1xWhWZo4lnw6QMVEr0xicHFrHlk4-3JI1scE5RvlflYfWVjA0Aw7Duq~9Gb0nOF6AVBZwbqrgzkT3T2~8vEBTtSWEbZBTZsS8XFUb7S2cc50yE7Hu5LyKYnzje2AK4W-U1e3VOsZ9Z0mpLBzTEfuBK7lQwB2J30J0X7iXQjg8JAsWtAN2TbOIvN7All7Tn-avqnb5sQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-m1.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">1</span></div> with \u03c1<sup>2</sup>=[(2 \u2212<em>e</em>) (<em>x</em>\u2212<em>x</em><sub>c</sub>)/2]<sup>2</sup>+[(2 \u2212<em>e</em>) (<em>y</em>\u2212<em>y</em><sub>c</sub>)/(2 \u2212 2<em>e</em>)]<sup>2</sup>, and (<em>x</em><sub>c</sub>, <em>y</em><sub>c</sub>) is the centre of the mass distribution (see also Sm05).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass models generally include a single dPIE component centred at the BCG location, but in some cases this description is unable to reproduce the observed multiple-image systems. When this is the case, we add a second or third cluster-scale mass component. A full discussion of our capacity to identify cluster-scale clumps from the strong-lensing signal is provided in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.3</a>.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In order to estimate the model dependence of our strong lensing results, we also independently fit the cluster-scale mass distributions with the same number of Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b55\" data-open=\"b55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Navarro, Frenk &amp; White 1997</a>) profiles, characterized by a concentration <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> and a scaleradius <em>r</em><sub>s</sub>, described by usual density profile: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m2\" content-id=\"m2\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0404-0325-m2.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-m2.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=CmkyCLRo-7cKFDF0pMTMhv2Mi0Fk8Gae90IZqcBH0hkVnfoNM2A8XRvs6l3cSE2f9mckxifN2b7noCR5J-MayGll1VLDUbYAzXje5fCSGReXnmHFYKrWaX0ElL0OnZ13GbebIDnmQ69-Xa9L~TbRfyU7RcXZ7AQ2qLW8HVGuW1X6iClw1oMZPejp-lYoNRb7JhY~j1Erf~mIuRyDI0dvzVj0UCQJqc8S25tNyenHiNATwr-S3i0zRIgDW0zq8FlB9rGGGbz3ly6mHiIJvug0sgGpAOctFIp6Bf~GVtNnA4KpTk5nH75uRx-ZpW8oria1QCAYY-Te~z~~LTkn5I~-Qg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-m2.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">2</span></div> where \u03c1<sub>c</sub> is the critical density and \u03b4<sub>c</sub> is related to <em>c</em><sub>200</sub> through the relation: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m3\" content-id=\"m3\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0404-0325-m3.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-m3.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=ypJVkQMPKTo7Pv0SmbpctXX1Je6VKbIavbZVXvKOBzsJdENJGeA36Ba0fUhCdqKZKkMFn3-eOOluS2uyvJY6lahQCwaFXHvjOpE~KduV70cL8bkUylbVseld~EpWTATJOKMYsKZZd9xMAYgjFH~DGQafgH5D39clNW62l~LHOLaUWwyXD5KMqBl9BNKI2jKylKt7O2nLTW6wWXYCyDgAwBjpbk~HCoVNw9J9FnSlOBs6DCu0VEl-KvAdJoHehsEht9xyToT9PQZWt~cyYa4uJOz9~9MJ-nCPU6-70ppzeFGxCWqVs7ScDCKiGnONO1sBf2LsaZ1OSuB3Lw~mRo5fQw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-m3.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">3</span></div> The generalization of this spherical model into a projected elliptical mass distribution follows a similar relation as <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-m1\"></span><a href=\"#m1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">equation (1)</a>. The full analytical description of the pseudo-elliptical NFW is presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Golse &amp; Kneib (2002)</a>.</div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680563 id=\"64680563\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2-2>3.2.2 Galaxy-scale mass component</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The presence of numerous cluster galaxies near the cluster centre as identified by our near-infrared photometric selection (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss2-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2.2.3</a>) affects the shape of the mass distribution locally, and therefore the associated lensing signal. Following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. (1996)</a> and Sm05, we account for galaxy-scale mass in the models by adding individual dPIE mass components at the location of each galaxy in the cluster catalogues discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss2-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2.2.3</a>, within 250 kpc of the respective BCGs. The geometrical parameters of these components (<em>x</em><sub>c</sub>, <em>y</em><sub>c</sub>, <em>e</em>, \u03b8) are matched to the values measured by SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span>. The parameters \u03c3<sub>0</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>core</sub> and <em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>, upon which the total mass of each galaxy-scale dark matter halo depend, are assumed to scale with their <em>K</em>-band luminosity <em>L<sub>K</sub></em>, relative to an <em>L</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub><em>K</em></sub> galaxy, following the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b26\" data-open=\"b26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Faber &amp; Jackson (1976)</a> relation and a constant mass-to-light ratio: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m4\" content-id=\"m4\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0404-0325-m4.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-m4.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=g32cY0FeB-eSQk9IbHC7XB1Vy8zKXaGAts5FgoD5P2GBbzfNepQMRqHZETee5NAF2X7p19FUNQZ0aJ5OGEfA3FhUBpj3PSx2ruVZme7B-4CZPw2cHit~psKEvyrbnCvksbRBoGogAajVoi5Ru5R5ZR5FOJC6sSuibDxSSuuWsbrg7n0MarPGOZDqXIRpiZ7G3aA0Tm7otpLJj8b78SQhDEgeqECcjQGY40IlrPpC-UgqMoeoENB6jZaXTHXHReb6qbpIkRu2N6AknwtlLPbRBcwGeJM-~bxhfVVg9obk35-F1lnFdjSqGjjTE8vUvDiq3rhog~d7O71~q4TKGsPQow__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-m4.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">4</span></div> Similar scaling relations have been used in the past (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Covone et al. 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007b</a>), showing that <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>core</sub> is small and has little effect on the modelling results. We therefore adopt <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>core</sub>= 0.15 kpc, following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2007b)</a>; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b11\" data-open=\"b11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Brainerd &amp; Specian (2003)</a>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The two remaining parameters (\u03c3<sup>\u2605</sup><sub>0</sub>, <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub>) are degenerate, because the perturbation of the cluster lensing signal caused by an individual galaxy depends on the total galaxy mass, given by \u03c3<sup>2</sup><sub>0</sub><em>r</em><sub>cut</sub>. After performing various tests with <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span>, we concluded that fixing one of these parameters does not affect the ability of the models to reproduce the observed multiple-image systems, provided that galaxies located within 2 arcsec of a highly magnified arc are excluded from the scaling relations (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2.3</a>). We therefore adopted a fixed <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub>= 45 kpc, which matches recent galaxy\u2013galaxy weak-lensing results (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b54\" data-open=\"b54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Natarajan et al. 2009</a>). For our adopted value of <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>core</sub>= 0.15 kpc, the measured galaxy velocity dispersions (\u03c3) and dPIE velocity dispersions (\u03c3<sub>0</sub>) are in good agreement \u20130.94 &lt; \u03c3/\u03c3<sub>0</sub> &lt; 1.04\u2013 the range of values arising from the range of radii at which \u03c3 is measured (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. 2007</a>). We therefore employ a Gaussian prior of \u03c3<sup>\u2605</sup><sub>0</sub>= (158 \u00b1 27) km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, making use of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b5\" data-open=\"b5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bernardi et al. (2003)</a>'s observational results on \u03c3<sup>\u2605</sup>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680566 id=\"64680566\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2-3>3.2.3 BCG and individual galaxy perturbers</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We model separately the BCG in each cluster using a similar dPIE profile as other cluster members, but optimizing the values of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu4.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=ZsB5yFkNDXnR3969pZfcsxXwXJzsPnGXud0yqlMXFeXh2SURdghThE857GRo2adDH38zmR34s7LEL67xN3X1ExUvJ0VkDFiWkcErSyG6hwe2Syus-JdRElz25jN3-PkMcz4qipFx09uGNF5q~T3-ZPgSbmSgL2SvKF-sFILJC4SiutQNG8LQNArLZK70JHy-Xp2v4n5gYoySuz04NvvBGqjtZ-c3n0gpJgB67YNlAaiW6jh8orxsAzdPbDtxIxeYAGpSc2qY1GZtY2vO1ma0Ee4qiOpiHPMpvDyI-ExUzZwsAO1E3atysIVaq5zeidghq~vJVJe3PWgsKeEStu6RRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu4.gif\" /></span> and <em>r</em><sub>cut,BCG</sub> independently. The same approach was used for six local galaxy-scale perturbers in A 611, A 773, A 1413, A 1835, identified in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680568 id=\"64680568\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-2-4>3.2.4 Optimization</h4>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The models are fitted to the multiple-image constraints using the new Bayesian MCMC sampler, described in detail in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jullo et al. (2007)</a>. This process uses the observational constraints (positions of the multiple-image systems) to optimize the parameters describing the mass distribution by matching the location of each image of a given system in the source plane. The quality of the models can be estimated using the rms deviation in the image plane from the observed positions of the multiple-image positions predicted by the model, defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"m5\" content-id=\"m5\"><div class=\"fig-graphic\"><div class=\"jumplink-placeholder\" id=\"mnras0404-0325-m5.gif\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-m5.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=j6aQpvF4qwVUi6UVxW6ADOgJOVb6ndn3FkzqBawccC8i2zZCRLdduaEhgyzjcsBRKi76s0pta7qIDFSriTig7-XZoD7er9auRhuTMngE3hSeKdpr8J1AVRO69OkQ2FAUpq1TiceXloES-UEpo~f-98TcQ53gb6Fm16-OOlcenTNjvKVE1jKty6-3iBHtA9OWIE5VRb9CkH87AeCIvdjKsJV2mb9RlT~m4GTsgMrQwWBkTe5U10zg3UXL3mWZTS8AsbMPSgOAGsirEo204stWhldJhWaNJSH2-s-rRLCXNJ~YAEN8tJu64e1zo1u4dqTwkio0axi04mEtVG5tydtmKA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"formula\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-m5.gif\" /></div></div></div><span class=\"label\">5</span></div> where (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060<img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu5.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=WeqS5eHzLxmD9BzU6639DGSGqrW3CHufdDoeefewX5u6ivVDKPaWRfQGHuRw0ugkGrFWkc2d7phZs5zGGs7RzX5sSFzlmZLPxoQXPeWENFpvmMK74Ie8cysYERg8qH6DH6xKtRPpz0s~X3IlnavOLIA4c4Ju~DQGWdwMsaG1IWDsz73u2M3zicsbxOjhadh6IQsRd8--oDO7eLTX0SpEViF1U~gWKvlAXGIQ-Hzsx6hqYx6oKlCkFvOjMBVPTO0piZ2-4bKwsjY~kk3yZxcur277h5fzDG6nCD5Ro4W8JgCPvkO2tZMXef24Sy-PfP00z0B-mKrj~M6VCPQs4EJcxA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu5.gif\" />\u2060</span>) and (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060<img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu6.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=yluV9ouDccd7HvdAAYMhmzNWJhNXSt2oozzZNObRDSeHyFF1RUu1nuhqS50TMCy22Ft5oOY-UI5kX69craHujT7gxKRDI-7W3-Obj3xfAq2ZrUrqLK5qS42W~t4~Q-Pcp73-BKGIdbnavlLXhJ8ZMDtjhsMqrLSyr-y43-iW7eRFlaThf3ZAsNxo6kxtg-fWNMx64i7Xd0ijd1jJvzO4LiA8cZkBgiLOEU00ZrkfW781q0bH~~K9Tc44jplEUDGe1qJbtikPYG2uE8LYlIA19qYsHw30ZcNhofrlTZimOXCWiVKOyh9slnXubUx0I-IaBCG6pppmiUsi5EGGYIb~rw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu6.gif\" />\u2060</span>) are the observed and predicted locations of image <em>j</em> in system <em>k</em>, respectively. Following Sm05, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. (2007b)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2009)</a>, we have used 0.2 arcsec as the positional uncertainty of the multiple-image identifications.</div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680570 id=\"64680570\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-3>3.3 Best-fitting parameters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The best-fitting parameters of the mass models are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t6\" data-open=\"t6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>, for both models that parametrize the cluster-scale mass components as dPIE and NFW profiles. The parameter uncertainties are based on the MCMC chains generated by <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b35\" data-open=\"b35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jullo et al. 2007</a>, for details). We obtain \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u2272 0.5 arcsec for 9/10 clusters, with 7/10 having \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u2272 0.2 arcsec. These results are typical of strong lensing studies using a similar number of multiples images (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2009</a>). However in the case of A 1835, where we have the largest number of multiple-image constraints (seven systems), we obtained \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u223c 3.15 arcsec, which is comparable with recent results on A 1689 (2.87 arcsec; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007b</a>) using 32 systems. We discuss the origin of this large value of \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> for A 1835 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680572\" scrollto-destination=\"64680572\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t6\" data-id=\"t6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the mass models. For each mass component, we give the centre, ellipticity, orientation, core and cut radii, as well as central velocity dispersion of the dPIE profile. The following column gives the image plane rms of this model, and the second rightmost columns present the best-fitting concentration and scaleradius of the corresponding NFW profile, used to derive the systematic errors on the model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Comp.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n \u00b1 0.19\u00a0</td><td>[\u221266.9]\u00a0</td><td>9.9 \u00b1 17.3\u00a0</td><td>[1000.0]\u00a0</td><td>539 \u00b1 143\u00a0</td><td>0.15\u00a0</td><td>13.9 \u00b1 3.2\u00a0</td><td>61.4 \u00b1 22\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"12\">RXJ2129\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DM1\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>0.46 \u00b1 0.15\u00a0</td><td>\u221216.4 \u00b1 2.5\u00a0</td><td>45.2 \u00b1 13.9\u00a0</td><td>[1000.0]\u00a0</td><td>755 \u00b1 98\u00a0</td><td>0.11\u00a0</td><td>5.9 \u00b1 2.0\u00a0</td><td>198.6 \u00b1 79.8\u00a0</td><td>0.23\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>BCG\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.0]\u00a0</td><td>[0.490]\u00a0</td><td>[\u221235.4]\u00a0</td><td>[0.172]\u00a0</td><td>[1.988]\u00a0</td><td>335 \u00b1 129\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>L* gal\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td>[45]\u00a0</td><td>229 \u00b1 35\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/64680572\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The best-fitting ellipticity <em>e</em> and position angle \u03b8 of the cluster-scale dark matter haloes are in good agreement between the dPIE and NFW models, with 0 \u2272<em>e</em>\u2272 0.7, and \u03b8 of the main cluster-scale halo agreeing with the orientation of the BCG. A few clusters have <em>e</em> &gt; 0.5; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b28\" data-open=\"b28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Golse &amp; Kneib (2002)</a> have shown that the pseudo-elliptical NFW profile presents a boxy/peanut shape at such high ellipticities. We therefore adopt the dPIE models as the fiducial models for the rest of the paper, and use the NFW models to quantify systematic errors in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For 8/10 clusters, a single dPIE or NFW cluster-scale dark matter halo is needed in addition to the cluster galaxies to reproduce accurately the observed multiple-image systems. However, for two clusters, the strong-lensing constraints reveal the influence of additional cluster-scale dark matter haloes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A 868: the overall shape of the giant arc providing the constraints in this cluster is quite straight, and slightly curved towards the second brightest galaxy instead of the cluster centre. This shows that it is mostly influenced by the presence of a secondary component, which we parametrize as centred on this second galaxy.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A 773: the large number of highly sheared arcs and multiple images show the presence of a dual component at the centre, as well as a third dark matter clump towards the east. Using the new spectroscopic redshifts of multiple images, we confirm the result of Sm05, who included three components in the lens model to explain the overall weak-lensing signal.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare the magnification factors \u03bc computed from the lens models with the photometry of each image in a given multiple system (last columns of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>). We find only a marginal agreement between the measured photometry and these magnifications, which is certainly due to the fact that the magnification factors are derived only at a single position, whereas many of the arcs are fairly extended, and also due to the surface brightness limits when measuring the photometry of the faintest images. The majority of the multiple images are strongly magnified, with typically \u03bc\u223c 2 mag (or 5\u201310 on linear scale). Errors on the magnification reach very large values (\u0394\u03bc &gt; 1 mag) for multiple images in the vicinity of the critical line (\u03bc\u2273 4 mag, or \u227330 on linear scale).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680578 id=\"64680578\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4>3.4 Systematic errors</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we discuss four systematic uncertainties in our mass models: inability of parametrized models to fit the multiple-image constraints in A 1835 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.1</a>), the impact of fixing the size of <em>L</em><sup>\u2605</sup> galaxies on the modelling results (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.2</a>), reliability of identification of substructures (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.3</a>) and choice of parametrization for cluster-scale dark matter haloes (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.4</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680580 id=\"64680580\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4-1>3.4.1 Quality of fit for A 1835</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We tried to improve the quality of the fit to the multiple-image constraints in A 1835 (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u2243 3 arcsec) by adding a secondary dPIE cluster-scale halo on the next brightest peaks seen on the <em>K</em>-band light map (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.3</a>), as well as allowing the positions of the main cluster-scale halo (previously with its centre fixed on that of the BCG) to be free parameters. This did not yield any significant improvements in the quality of the fit. The high value of \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is due to the inability of the parametrized model to reproduce simultaneously the multiple-image systems located to the north and the south of the BCG. It therefore appears that the main limitation of the current model for this cluster is the assumption of elliptical symmetry in the mass components.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To explore this, we used the new, more flexible method presented by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b34\" data-open=\"b34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Jullo &amp; Kneib (2009)</a> that employs a multiscale adaptive grid to refine a parametric model that is constrained by a large number of strong lensing constraints \u2013 thus dropping the assumption of elliptical symmetry. The resulting mass map shows a mass extension to the north of the BCG and less extended to the south, compared to the original dPIE model. The quality of the fit is improved to \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>= 1.7 arcsec for the same multiple-image systems. The lack of spectroscopic redshifts in the northern multiple images precludes strong conclusions about this asymmetry. Securing spectroscopic redshifts for these multiple-image systems is therefore a necessary step to further improve this mass model. Overall, the absence of a secondary cluster-scale component in the simple dPIE model and the wide distribution of multiple-image galaxies across the cluster core reassure us that the absolute calibration of the total mass, Einstein radius and cluster substructure are reasonably accurate.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680583 id=\"64680583\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4-2>3.4.2 Fixed size of L<sup>\u2605</sup><em>cluster galaxies</em></h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that other galaxy\u2013galaxy weak-lensing works have obtained different values for <em>r</em>*<sub>cut</sub>, but within the range 10 &lt; <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub> &lt; 100 kpc (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b53\" data-open=\"b53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Natarajan, Kneib &amp; Smail 2002</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b31\" data-open=\"b31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Halkola, Seitz &amp; Pannella 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b42\" data-open=\"b42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007a</a>). To quantify how much our choice of <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub>= 45 kpc (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2.2</a>) affects mass model results, we therefore ran the following test: we included <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub> as a free parameter for the five models having the largest number of constraints (i.e. A 611, A 773, A 1413, A 1835 and Z 2701), allowing it to vary in the range (10\u2013100) kpc. The best-fitting parameters and quality of fit (judged by \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>) of these five models are all consistent with the fiducial models in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t6\" data-open=\"t6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>, specifically the best-fitting values of <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub> are all consistent with <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub>= 45 kpc within their respective statistical uncertainties. The degeneracy between <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub> and \u03c3<sup>\u2605</sup> also obeys the expected <em>r</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub>cut</sub>\u03c3<sup>\u26052</sup>= constant relation \u2013 i.e. a constant amount of mass is assigned to galaxy-size haloes (within 10 per cent) regardless of the specific values of these two parameters. This folds through to an uncertainty of just 15 per cent on the cluster substructure fractions, which is negligible in comparison with the statistical errors.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680585 id=\"64680585\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4-3>3.4.3 Identification of massive substructures</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The necessity to or not to add a second or third cluster-scale mass component to reproduce the observed multiple-image systems has been determined by the number and location of the strong-lensing constraints. The presence of massive substructures has direct implications on the substructure measurements discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>. We therefore test the fiducial mass models by comparing quantitatively the distribution of <em>K</em>-band light in the cluster cores with the mass modelling results.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We constructed <em>K</em>-band luminosity density maps from the cluster galaxy catalogues discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2-2-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss2-2-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2.2.3</a>, with a Gaussian smoothing scale of FWHM = 20 arcsec (corresponding to \u223c70 kpc at <em>z</em>= 0.2), which is the smallest scale over which we measured the influence of a secondary clump on the strong lensing images. The location of the highest peak (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060<img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu7.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=UbPHx7a0FrCwZ~Z2krCYa6zNc2y6dHrGLUBaD6XPUpWun-OXhDGZQjpObj7SI5Qhj8C~QGSTOO0NSAegBMRtWjTj8RMBC4gv1u6NRf~A59TvjmUmuEDERrm2IwaIkWcQLLEOpXvpcDIvWQwOszL65UQrEpD9evBcvja8CQkSg~rAZWR0OkwU-HjrBiZ7XfDnjb~4ve9iZLgqZwxjsjmr0PLicp3gD4CQNCFIa21MRgGLCwOclCj3HOnyW7NeKefV1PakpnOX1OmGrLQVHqa-3EabX~4gJHxfYR7Ag-JGK97J2xn03g8Rqmdrfrj41d0FyE1TpQ~flZb2ocCNkKVuRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu7.gif\" />\u2060</span>) in the <em>K</em>-band light maps always coincides (within 1 arcsec) with the centre of the cluster-scale mass distribution. We searched for secondary peaks in the <em>K</em>-band light by adopting a threshold <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu8.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=CBrD0rMRyYpkuddOGbK9kp3eWXDisSoznM265KoEHjtIxlJIinbPzJckmg3qbr~CQ3rjITdFmW2C6nct2zhfH60EUhrML3HmyQajVdLMQ6EmrwNS8Mg6lCTsIeEM7c2T1OxHb2E2R9ukhqXWuDBguhEKv2i~Wb8IKYhsaYrsBs0DlEml99AZdjIS4mJY4-VXsoWLMm3tkZiDyBERUx2JvBPovZ1onCUh51U5xefx49~ewuZxCDj7ow1~J8f2H78CqiZkpouPzhI2JaCxPgfqdLNDxhKw6ngFMEwu3yblO8I3PsLD9yPcVHoPv4SedPMONP2RaNsm1nYYKz9Slk2NQQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu8.gif\" /></span> and look for the local maxima within these regions (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>, white crosses). When comparing their location with the cluster-scale dark matter clumps, we find that every local maximum is coincident with a cluster-scale mass component in our models within the modelling errors (1 arcsec), except for the secondary peak in A 521 (located \u223c1 arcmin south of the BCG). It therefore appears that we are unable to detect this structure because the strong-lensing constraints lie exclusively north of the BCG. The presence of substructure in A 521 is consistent with the dynamical study of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maurogordato et al. (2000)</a>, who identified many large-scale components in A 521, and suggested that it is a highly disturbed merging cluster. Our inability to detect any of these structures may explain why A 521 is an outlier in the <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>\u2212\u0394<em>m</em><sub>12</sub> relation discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.2.2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680588\" scrollto-destination=\"64680588\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=Z6ZCURPUELskI3-DS3xe9wq8EiQFzdlxkY99vGbcLEjQ5D7lCHnAa7k4o4b~b1nkh2dgc2sShfF7~3VAHgxQHNlXvXmum05NECCC8Jd9qxprKMnno-PGhDNK8DPG05k5eq2TvR8lLrjX1SA2Tf741uKpYe0cj3gZVpG2SiT5GStOP8ppIlc~oL56edMvqWN6apE70Y0bkKwRCzmbbOVfDD99IiSTWunpCPpaI6lUxPqaYzRAtHHQiId6BZnPpw62uMNLwHz0BFnPDECh0AGGEiiSXJS~IagT9UlvP5KnPPowDJ4EQRbtqu7GZDe7-neks22Ags9qYiSmGpClu1xFfQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"K-band cluster luminosity density maps (grey scale) smoothed with an FWHM = 20 arcsec Gaussian. The white contours show the selection of K-band light peaks as local maxima (crosses; see Section 3.4.3 for details).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680588/mnras0404-0325-f3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680588\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f3.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=nvKOkDFPQQeCyJ8amllOSy-h5UyaWhri4mNVUc3-wLUkUrOmcCZ5pjdU4mr-lRdF~umkfkMlbanV5oQaFykTADHASTUCFJxt-hQoXtpP25z0OyGp6XxVhDRUt8aRMusWPBgJMbsqSFK5Wv8fgAG6Z~1EBrEF33BNqgfrpRrojz~WuNiAQS4hIWs1xqRsGGtxiQnbhU1ESlbHBOeyqYjuhX6S2z9ecVMtFk6ktToRiqxV8v1cVodW4~jDe5kbPWo9ZJ1FSY~cm~pUFhyQXpCGU3-LQitGkoz4yP9Wvt8~OQfqJHxSqQElKIERKLtyvNx4OHH5riQ9xFjAxTGw8Mr8IQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680588&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>K</em>-band cluster luminosity density maps (grey scale) smoothed with an FWHM = 20 arcsec Gaussian. Red contours show the reconstructed dark matter distribution with a constant logarithmic scale. The white contours show the selection of <em>K</em>-band light peaks as local maxima (crosses; see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-4-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.4.3</a> for details).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680589 id=\"64680589\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss3-4-4>3.4.4 Parametrization of dark haloes</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To examine the amplitude of any systematic error in cluster mass measurement arising from choice of dPIE or NFW mass profiles, we show the projected mass profiles <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em>) in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f4\" data-open=\"f4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 4</a> from both dPIE and NFW models. The statistical error on <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em>) is typically 0.05\u20130.2 dex, depending on the number of lensing constraints. We find a general agreement between the <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em>) profiles obtained from the best-fitting dPIE and NFW models, and use the average difference between the two as an estimate of the systematic error made by assuming a specific cluster-scale profile \u2013 this systematic error is comparable with the statistical errors.</p>                        <a id=\"64680591\" scrollto-destination=\"64680591\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=O6~aNqJWH7WMExVxyEHEk1BL5DI-qNoV2H02nSc-S9AFspZfAu5qP3O6yRbttQQrMi2kqQdtv1Oqlx1tdvo2yL~pVVslhk4FqfufnJUzKLzi7iahJOaLDqi1BeWU4YjesPOCAqF~TtKwR-HlrRPyyQDULj6eExdKpB3RnVzTZ4LTJT1mJ3dFGqRjTNew-hhSc4edLV3t-P1kUnYuIS~qNX7qfp6Ue3lQ3voX39kslWbvLeLiYxMUdE67FUzhAVVtZOS54LePkOAt-N7Amhdf7b2OK31pfLn2gHtzz-B6grRiFvPm8TqtJCNIVssWKVDAxpElbUkdtANgpEuhKsq66w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Integrated mass profiles assuming a dPIE (solid grey) or an NFW (hatched red) profile for the dark matter distribution. The arrows mark the distance of the multiple images used as constraints in each cluster, and the vertical dashed corresponds to the radius of 250 kpc used to derive the enclosed masses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680591/mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680591\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=z7gErPVRZfxbnPyQCp-RoKHjL4XlZ~DJRz3n6GtTNjqYJQ-W1pI1--yQiSk47noSjVRHLOhEa4TbpyWjJryWePo3-sP6ND6GtvAF87z0tMPyzZm7HWy1lj~pbEN67EPXERAQ4Va8zhTdjfA5UxGmS6~OOUssks4BCuX9paRXxzULBLs4XAbrKbgDyi7WUyBrefSww1trQdZQWQnwW-pK6KKLqBVb2SuRYbGdZMOexUOpr5kr5DqmGuk8Sr0mw9VyDDVy5CmvPdwa8t~J1WzbaWYs4O2UeZHjLS5K1YcaYnwrGNMPNNCPbLz4HyISmoeYNG~i6bSD2FNC2v0pKkbnXQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680591&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Integrated mass profiles assuming a dPIE (solid grey) or an NFW (hatched red) profile for the dark matter distribution. The arrows mark the distance of the multiple images used as constraints in each cluster, and the vertical dashed corresponds to the radius of 250 kpc used to derive the enclosed masses.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=O6~aNqJWH7WMExVxyEHEk1BL5DI-qNoV2H02nSc-S9AFspZfAu5qP3O6yRbttQQrMi2kqQdtv1Oqlx1tdvo2yL~pVVslhk4FqfufnJUzKLzi7iahJOaLDqi1BeWU4YjesPOCAqF~TtKwR-HlrRPyyQDULj6eExdKpB3RnVzTZ4LTJT1mJ3dFGqRjTNew-hhSc4edLV3t-P1kUnYuIS~qNX7qfp6Ue3lQ3voX39kslWbvLeLiYxMUdE67FUzhAVVtZOS54LePkOAt-N7Amhdf7b2OK31pfLn2gHtzz-B6grRiFvPm8TqtJCNIVssWKVDAxpElbUkdtANgpEuhKsq66w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Integrated mass profiles assuming a dPIE (solid grey) or an NFW (hatched red) profile for the dark matter distribution. The arrows mark the distance of the multiple images used as constraints in each cluster, and the vertical dashed corresponds to the radius of 250 kpc used to derive the enclosed masses.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680591/mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680591\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=z7gErPVRZfxbnPyQCp-RoKHjL4XlZ~DJRz3n6GtTNjqYJQ-W1pI1--yQiSk47noSjVRHLOhEa4TbpyWjJryWePo3-sP6ND6GtvAF87z0tMPyzZm7HWy1lj~pbEN67EPXERAQ4Va8zhTdjfA5UxGmS6~OOUssks4BCuX9paRXxzULBLs4XAbrKbgDyi7WUyBrefSww1trQdZQWQnwW-pK6KKLqBVb2SuRYbGdZMOexUOpr5kr5DqmGuk8Sr0mw9VyDDVy5CmvPdwa8t~J1WzbaWYs4O2UeZHjLS5K1YcaYnwrGNMPNNCPbLz4HyISmoeYNG~i6bSD2FNC2v0pKkbnXQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680591&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Integrated mass profiles assuming a dPIE (solid grey) or an NFW (hatched red) profile for the dark matter distribution. The arrows mark the distance of the multiple images used as constraints in each cluster, and the vertical dashed corresponds to the radius of 250 kpc used to derive the enclosed masses.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680592 id=\"64680592\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4>4 THE MASS AND STRUCTURE OF CLUSTER CORES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we use the strong lens models of the full sample of 20 clusters to construct a statistical sample of measurements of the mass and structure of cluster cores, for comparison with theoretical predictions. Despite the modest statistical significance achieved in these comparisons, due to the sample size, this is so far the largest sample of strong-lensing clusters analysed in a uniform manner and represents a four-fold increase on the strong-lensing clusters studied by Sm05. Most importantly, these results provide a statistical context within which to view results from detailed analysis of spectacular individual cluster lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We begin by describing integrated cluster masses and related quantities such as Einstein radii in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1</a>, and then concentrate on structural quantities such as substructure fractions and cluster ellipticities in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.2</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680595 id=\"64680595\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1>4.1 Cluster masses and Einstein radii</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680596 id=\"64680596\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1-1>4.1.1 Einstein radii</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first measure the effective Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub> of each cluster at <em>z<sub>S</sub></em>= 2. \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is defined as the angular radius \u03b8 from the centre of the cluster at which the average convergence <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu9.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=eFvEe8eKltOc8s2XobKcDD~-Iz9VoACXqrcng2Ms9AEFgN~76Jxup6bP0h3UiXpSVjXT-jZ9xGF5l0kUyRTCWncSz8QGjpqAEX0y8auSfSNDV0tvG8e5Jypuz2Y0gN1CdbGi0uLvZkEgClh~1RBf0IhG2GCd5PnqNfLjRyl5q8hxzus9welZIyJTIRRpAA3goEfhYT457GDeowyL5NBEFyONWZ22abHjI22Wd9GXOkIpqVRhsWMOd5xJNGpkVV-fhKD0EPkb2iHGnJ7Ov1ocRH4FiKpyCgF9GiEoHyLiUal0C2ASd8WdiskPut7MSND1MnjHko8mN2CKvv4boJwcdA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu9.gif\" /></span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>). We choose <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2 because this is the typical redshift of the spectroscopically confirmed multiple-image galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>). Values of \u03b8<sub>E</sub> range between \u223c4 and 47 arcsec are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t7\" data-open=\"t7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>, and the distribution is plotted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>. The \u03b8<sub>E</sub> distribution is best fitted by a lognormal distribution with \u3008log<sub>10</sub>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u3009= 1.16 \u00b1 0.28, where \u03b8<sub>E</sub> is measured in arcseconds. Two clusters (A 1689 and Abell 1703) are in common between this study and the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana (2008)</a> sample of clusters with large Einstein radii. These two clusters are located at 2\u03c3 and 1.5\u03c3 above \u3008log<sub>10</sub>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u3009, suggesting that \u223c2.3 and \u223c6.7 per cent of clusters found in larger sample will have \u03b8<sub>E</sub> at least as large as those of A 1689 and A 1703, respectively.</p>                        <a id=\"64680598\" scrollto-destination=\"64680598\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t7\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t7\" data-id=\"t7\"><span class=\"label\">Table 7</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The mass and structure of the cluster cores inferred from the strong-lensing mass models, plus related quantities from the near-infrared cluster galaxy catalogues.</p></div> lensed galaxies used to constrain the mass model. <sup><em>b</em></sup>Whether the strong-lensing constraints include a radial image pair. <sup><em>c</em></sup>Projected mass within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc in units of 10<sup>14</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>.<sup><em>d</em></sup>Ellipticity of mass distribution in the cluster core inferred from the projected mass maps.</p></span></div></div><div       </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"64680599\" scrollto-destination=\"64680599\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label alt=\"The observed distribution of effective Einstein radii for a source at zs= 2.0 (solid black histogram), and best-fitting lognormal distribution (black dotted line). We also plot the predicted distribution based on the NFW model parameters (Table 6) and the predicted distributions of halo properties in strong-lensing selected simulated clusters \u2013 see Section 4.1.1 for more details.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680599/mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680599\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=CFGIkbZ2H48a0XTlqVFS79XCUVQOpwOysnc4SJtVRIeLP8IXNzYZk4xUbkF~DwXugzZZCavK6aGf~wuvm~ndcefzvv2E0fMrOVvltEPxewxHGyNT02YopA4P2Uswwhs-N-Phkn-QPFwklGQKF5wQpSA2iPFg613~6vvPwh6HNP-uq-2e3irwhuxfV6bsQNpf77dyUzAlHOYvqqpv8ZmNHfNfCttyXlcH966D81jfSAyjdcFiA-D4IxX3xTVEvOU2RLnbEwBAXX39jrBLQrFMppy5q9EXsJ9Cf4w9EzlW7mxrb2osa3ptKZ3gu0QxSCgfMj74IPxr9UKwQOi~Elwsmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680599&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed distribution of effective Einstein radii for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2.0 (solid black histogram), and best-fitting lognormal distribution (black dotted line). We also plot the predicted distribution based on the NFW model parameters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t6\" data-open=\"t6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>) and the predicted distributions of halo properties in strong-lensing selected simulated clusters \u2013 see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1.1</a> for more details.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=MjsMd-MnnzrGdwNa0zJYTs7cJp7W3y1A1IYFX7UFhI~MslSalYQAh2G7Ruz8~0g1e21AMU0ooCHbzFoW7HSt01A38zAYL-F8Xdn94MdO9WLXkqIHzpEFqYxEifvigMOuSewYL6fyB-usmXbCDxcm2qcqEo18DdUhdYMLJ5OZStFwdTn296I46vGY2WecxlJfT2A9G9rUYnIgGRKA09RWq0JxXIzgDQA1aYraHj3-L5~XOqAadZKHdccBxnmlwruR1GJmaIvMYLzR3mJT1SSasEt51EYhTnoqTHZVFmHEIhBOevmyjZ~iFHrX9G4qYFd5nI7MjlZ2FQ27eCUZDa~A-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The observed distribution of effective Einstein radii for a source at zs= 2.0 (solid black histogram), and best-fitting lognormal distribution (black dotted line). We also plot the predicted distribution based on the NFW model parameters (Table 6) and the predicted distributions of halo properties in strong-lensing selected simulated clusters \u2013 see Section 4.1.1 for more details.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680599/mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680599\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=CFGIkbZ2H48a0XTlqVFS79XCUVQOpwOysnc4SJtVRIeLP8IXNzYZk4xUbkF~DwXugzZZCavK6aGf~wuvm~ndcefzvv2E0fMrOVvltEPxewxHGyNT02YopA4P2Uswwhs-N-Phkn-QPFwklGQKF5wQpSA2iPFg613~6vvPwh6HNP-uq-2e3irwhuxfV6bsQNpf77dyUzAlHOYvqqpv8ZmNHfNfCttyXlcH966D81jfSAyjdcFiA-D4IxX3xTVEvOU2RLnbEwBAXX39jrBLQrFMppy5q9EXsJ9Cf4w9EzlW7mxrb2osa3ptKZ3gu0QxSCgfMj74IPxr9UKwQOi~Elwsmw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680599&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed distribution of effective Einstein radii for a source at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>= 2.0 (solid black histogram), and best-fitting lognormal distribution (black dotted line). We also plot the predicted distribution based on the NFW model parameters (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t6\" data-open=\"t6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a>) and the predicted distributions of halo properties in strong-lensing selected simulated clusters \u2013 see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1.1</a> for more details.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of observed Einstein radii with theoretical predictions from numerical simulations is problematic because the simulations require both sufficiently large volume to contain a large sample of clusters as massive as observed systems and sufficient numerical resolution to allow \u03b8<sub>E</sub> to be measured reliably from the simulated data. Even modern simulations such as the Millennium Simulation are unable to satisfy both requirements, the main shortcoming being the simulation volume. Nevertheless, it is interesting to make a comparison. We therefore take the best-fitting mass and concentration of the 10 NFW models in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t6\" data-open=\"t6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 6</a> and convolve the measured concentrations with the predicted concentration distributions in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana (2008)</a>. We then calculate the predicted \u03b8<sub>E</sub> distributions and sum them to produce the red dashed curve in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f5\" data-open=\"f5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 5</a>. This distribution is much broader than the observed distribution, mainly because the virial masses of the NFW models are poorly constrained by strong-lensing constraints alone. In spite of this, we find that the predicted distribution peaks at \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u2243 5 arcsec, a factor of 2 lower than the observed distribution. This difference may be caused by an important difference between the simulations and observations, namely the presence of baryons in observed universe and the absence of them from the simulations. However, it is interesting to note that in a recent weak-lensing study of similarly sized sample <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. (2009)</a> found that the normalization of the mass concentration of observed clusters is roughly a factor of 2 higher than predicted from numerical simulations. The physical origin of both differences, if confirmed by larger samples, may be similar.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680601 id=\"64680601\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1-2>4.1.2 Projected mass measurements</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We show projected mass maps of the 10 new strong-lensing clusters in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f3\" data-open=\"f3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 3</a>, and integrate these maps and their equivalents for the extended sample to measure the projected mass of the cluster cores <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc)\u2013 see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t7\" data-open=\"t7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>. The mass measurements for the extended sample were based on the published dPIE models of these clusters listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Tables 2</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t9\" data-open=\"t9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>, adjusted to the cosmology used in this paper where relevant. The aperture of <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc is chosen because this ensures that the region within we measure mass lies within the <em>HST</em> field of view for all clusters; it is also approximately two times the largest observed Einstein radius within this sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compare the <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc) distribution of the current sample with the 10 clusters studied by Sm05 in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f6\" data-open=\"f6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 6</a>, and fit a lognormal distribution to both samples, obtaining \u3008log<sub>10</sub>(<em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>)\u3009= 14.29 \u00b1 0.19 and 14.27 \u00b1 0.17 for our sample and Sm05, respectively. This confirms that both studies are probing clusters of the same mass, which is consistent with close match in the range of X-ray luminosity probed: 4.3 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup>\u2264<em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2264 22.8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the case of Sm05 and 3.5 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup>\u2264<em>L</em><sub>X</sub>\u2264 22.8 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup> here (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t7\" data-open=\"t7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"64680604\" scrollto-destination=\"64680604\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\"
