masses (measured in a projected radius of 250 kpc) for the Sm05 sample (dashed histogram) and the current sample (solid histogram).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=1KK8un~T8Ge1E8kDnks3e-iCAWM0IzSG-Iok7OjSFuu1gqpMzgT~sv0ozhXLg1Gzyz~q8Z88tVvqQcpG0Lz2hYkcJt8QanE7T6WF7W-NSqxzSPFs6slCEeVV0unmIk8hvsa9tMF5SKUqEKPcbp2~Z4b~Tp44dx6tvMwcUIZ47fiyGGFVhNUgwrtsNSYzlKWclp4lT4vQxepMsw5e3UIn7ajjDJGBAMgKcX5IXm0e3WnM8GbuGtLjUXbpEnOC06dC9EdKpcckdrFeqxJp0Xtf~VVKWpdL5cPHSPmEieMonnmViRTs2ZD5ungZE2slT79sAiXj1JEHRdDhsdvKJsPb3A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Probability distribution of lensing masses (measured in a projected radius of 250 kpc) for the Sm05 sample (dashed histogram) and the current sample (solid histogram).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680604/mnras0404-0325-f6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680604\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f6.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=sRMKYCOTfAfK2JtFKW6c-qGBYYZ-nkPF1vzSxnY8qJ9uHveJz0ODhq-0cxChNNRNOWz0mtdEiWVnQGGSB5T74WtT3vRBkSAqqmsTzNC6a~ooEA1EhuNw8Pn38raslaEDkZpMzRDqHhFzJe1kFET7A5YG2Jljc~GnZQep9tuTMFwKLlrdyugksYLr4sWayuUyY5fmuycTyYomJufXI-bv-38rSxvA-c6sLUTjPw1laZyA-mTQvQTgqgw-uPbsIifwExCyKATOnl8ryoRbNCxUURcIXEqu2iiwhDytz3TnRe1tiFwinpnh-BhKD9ER3pq0yFeXh2POndl11t8L-hzRRQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680604&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Probability distribution of lensing masses (measured in a projected radius of 250 kpc) for the Sm05 sample (dashed histogram) and the current sample (solid histogram).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also plot in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f7\" data-open=\"f7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 7</a> the relationship between \u03b8<sub>E</sub> and <em>M</em>(&lt;250 kpc), revealing a clear positive linear correlation between the two quantities, as is expected from the properties of analytic descriptions of dark matter density profiles from simulations. The best-fitting relation for the whole sample is \u03b8<sub>E</sub>= (\u221214.7 \u00b1 4.7) + (13.8 \u00b1 2.5) <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>; the best-fitting relations for cool-core and non-cool-core subsamples are both statistically indistinguishable from this relation. However, we find that disturbed clusters tend to lie below the best-fitting relation for the full sample \u2013 indeed, we obtain best-fitting relations of: \u03b8<sub>E</sub>= (\u22128.6 \u00b1 4.5) + (9.75 \u00b1 2.3) <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub> and \u03b8<sub>E</sub>= (\u221214.7 \u00b1 5.0) + (14.0 \u00b1 2.2) <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub> for disturbed and undisturbed clusters, respectively. We interpret this as implying that disturbed clusters have flatter density profiles than undisturbed clusters of comparable mass. This is likely due to a combination of (i) the cluster\u2013cluster mergers that are likely to both soften the density profile and cause the observed disturbance (i.e. cause the offset between the X-ray and optical centres of the clusters) and (ii) disturbed clusters tending to have their merger axis preferentially aligned in the plane of the sky, thus making the disturbance possible to measure. This latter point is of particular importance with respect to A 1689, because this cluster is classified as undisturbed despite there being strong evidence for it being a line-of-sight merger (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007b</a>). If this cluster were viewed side-on then it would probably lie below the relation for undisturbed clusters, and be classified as disturbed.</p>                        <a id=\"64680606\" scrollto-destination=\"64680606\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=YWU9TqrMyW8lCQ1CyDFtfveyCManxJdiFOcEQzqhj3yPffs7B1dV~tIcPTVZF7L~b9Xi-duXNZaRz0Z-2Aay1xi2WkqAUxOR9jB66Teixiy09KFeESdNH1pymy~yUgWIdkEkhLWsm8gsXaPlnJS66Fmahmiq6FdnX9DCEd6FVoLxQXqJ0Mg6tRyZ769JVCc0NfEJf4D5PFd4k6~1bC9qLSW0Ln9e--Sv5ikY-bfXLQQnpSMhws0tNOH0tlHgvcJlvGD4OJm4m~kK~BlrO9~U0ktlz6-msvu-g9rXYVLS-euvqeuNV6ykStCybrw~Sij6QAegs2TtIHfGVWb31k9FCw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Effective Einstein radius (assuming a z= 2 source) versus strong-lensing mass (measured within 250 kpc). Red diamonds denote disturbed clusters and blue triangles undisturbed clusters. Filled symbols are the new strong-lensing models and open symbols are taken from the extended sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680606/mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680606\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=VQFXR6tkeqIvUE0U83SD~3tmIx1LPiYLszzNjVAQZt6-K0jMD0anYQ3u4m14FW9-Io68BPP2ZKflduyNFXpQHVG1~sDAfUyhQeKMjIDy285JxOaW5PTBvHpVH1uvwze3q8FdOC6qFjqupc2dvoiotg--OgvdVdX7kaoWIPu5HwVFXuKokXRgshiJP~Koi8Itky1fqukoKVVmjwKk-Zf2QJfM2rJAi-6mvdzanQI9RIPksZmAEo6SFPPeLRsjLv7O9-dNlwtBMKz85hA2vN79xrHmT7n3zt9hO6Q4EcQFlxO2MLMkBRWHFqaunoIRRaaL9vQ1UfLKzesWSlLBDK3iPA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680606&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Effective Einstein radius (assuming a <em>z</em>= 2 source) versus strong-lensing mass (measured within 250 kpc). The lines show the general trends when least-squared fitting a linear relation for all clusters (black solid line), undisturbed clusters (blue dashed line) and disturbed clusters (red dotted line). Red diamonds denote disturbed clusters and blue triangles undisturbed clusters. Filled symbols are the new strong-lensing models and open symbols are taken from the extended sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=YWU9TqrMyW8lCQ1CyDFtfveyCManxJdiFOcEQzqhj3yPffs7B1dV~tIcPTVZF7L~b9Xi-duXNZaRz0Z-2Aay1xi2WkqAUxOR9jB66Teixiy09KFeESdNH1pymy~yUgWIdkEkhLWsm8gsXaPlnJS66Fmahmiq6FdnX9DCEd6FVoLxQXqJ0Mg6tRyZ769JVCc0NfEJf4D5PFd4k6~1bC9qLSW0Ln9e--Sv5ikY-bfXLQQnpSMhws0tNOH0tlHgvcJlvGD4OJm4m~kK~BlrO9~U0ktlz6-msvu-g9rXYVLS-euvqeuNV6ykStCybrw~Sij6QAegs2TtIHfGVWb31k9FCw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Effective Einstein radius (assuming a z= 2 source) versus strong-lensing mass (measured within 250 kpc). The lines show the general trends when least-squared fitting a linear relation for all clusters (black solid line), undisturbed clusters (blue dashed line) and disturbed clusters (red dotted line). Red diamonds denote disturbed clusters and blue triangles undisturbed clusters. Filled symbols are the new strong-lensing models and open symbols are taken from the extended sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680606/mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680606\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=VQFXR6tkeqIvUE0U83SD~3tmIx1LPiYLszzNjVAQZt6-K0jMD0anYQ3u4m14FW9-Io68BPP2ZKflduyNFXpQHVG1~sDAfUyhQeKMjIDy285JxOaW5PTBvHpVH1uvwze3q8FdOC6qFjqupc2dvoiotg--OgvdVdX7kaoWIPu5HwVFXuKokXRgshiJP~Koi8Itky1fqukoKVVmjwKk-Zf2QJfM2rJAi-6mvdzanQI9RIPksZmAEo6SFPPeLRsjLv7O9-dNlwtBMKz85hA2vN79xrHmT7n3zt9hO6Q4EcQFlxO2MLMkBRWHFqaunoIRRaaL9vQ1UfLKzesWSlLBDK3iPA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680606&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Effective Einstein radius (assuming a <em>z</em>= 2 source) versus strong-lensing mass (measured within 250 kpc). The lines show the general trends when least-squared fitting a linear relation for all clusters (black solid line), undisturbed clusters (blue dashed line) and disturbed clusters (red dotted line). Red diamonds denote disturbed clusters and blue triangles undisturbed clusters. Filled symbols are the new strong-lensing models and open symbols are taken from the extended sample.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680607 id=\"64680607\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-1-3>4.1.3 Comparison of lensing and X-ray mass measurements</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We further investigate the integrated mass of the cluster cores within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc by comparing the <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub> with masses measured within the same aperture from the X-ray models discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2.4</a>. We used least-squared minimization, taking account of errors in both quantities to find the best-fitting parameters of the relation: <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>=<em>B</em><em>M</em><sub>X</sub>. For the full sample, we obtain a best fit of log<sub>10</sub>(<em>B</em>) = 0.13 \u00b1 0.04, i.e. a mean X-ray/lensing mass discrepancy of a factor of <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub>= 1.3 at \u223c3\u03c3 significance.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We then fit the same relations for the cool-core/non-cool-core as well as disturbed/undisturbed cluster subsamples, and report the best-fitting values in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t8\" data-open=\"t8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 8</a>. We find that the disturbed/undisturbed subsamples are statistically undistinguishable from both each other and the entire sample. However, we find that the normalization, log<sub>10</sub>(<em>B</em>), of the relation for non-cool-core clusters is 2\u03c3 higher than for cool-core clusters. These differences are illustrated in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680610\" scrollto-destination=\"64680610\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t8\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t8\" data-id=\"t8\"><span class=\"label\">Table 8</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters for the relationship between <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc) and <em>M</em><sub>X</sub>(<em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc) discussed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1.3</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Sample<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n log<sub>10</sub>(<em>B</em>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Scatter \u03c3<sub><em>M</em></sub> (dex)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Undisturbed\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>0.15 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Disturbed\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>0.12 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.15\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Sample<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n log<sub>10</sub>(<em>B</em>)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Scatter \u03c3<sub><em>M</em></sub> (dex)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>All<sup><em>b</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>18\u00a0</td><td>0.13 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.17\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Cool core\u00a0</td><td>8\u00a0</td><td>0.05 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.19\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Non cool core\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0</td><td>0.17 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Undisturbed\u00a0</td><td>12\u00a0</td><td>0.15 \u00b1 0.05\u00a0</td><td>0.20\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Disturbed\u00a0</td><td>6\u00a0</td><td>0.12 \u00b1 0.04\u00a0</td><td>0.15\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-t8_note24\"></span><div content-id=\"t8_note24\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> The number of clusters in each subsample are taken from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" The lines show the general trends when least-squared fitting a linear relation for all clusters (black solid line), cool-core clusters (blue dashed line) and non-cool-core clusters (red dotted line). Blue triangles denote cool-core clusters and red diamonds non-cool-core clusters. Filled symbols are the new strong-lensing models and open symbols are taken from the extended sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680611/mnras0404-0325-f8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680611\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f8.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=EuoO~IZIHuXNrcRpRtfUzmCvQsBDUhI~2SwN-Yfjj17zi4ynuoUM8pn2vuJQYJ3XZfmj318xHaKpAx8mSSM8EWYEq~NRemFIdB5v~lXiuvbW2zSBKd~9dhxEWPYDuBvug4bJ-r997lyWHM3fXR43Mjmk30SBQRGALKB3IWtyskzArohgwj0KAyl-Rr1POQkC8exxwlLkmg6F1h6OXXYLEyzuEJE476tJ8H1NEPPvvgFGrIWpq-D6qSIq2SvAHygIkI5FFKegbwulq3sXU3HxTogaqhFtmVbezUFnyNeeMZ2-wFIRNWGFyDN2-hb0TIfAFpU53BLQEnStuLfkXiTHTw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680611&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relationship between <em>M</em><sub>X</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>, both measured within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc. The lines show the general trends when least-squared fitting a linear relation for all clusters (black solid line), cool-core clusters (blue dashed line) and non-cool-core clusters (red dotted line). Blue triangles denote cool-core clusters and red diamonds non-cool-core clusters. Filled symbols are the new strong-lensing models and open symbols are taken from the extended sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To test the link between the agreement between lensing and X-ray mass measurements and the mass estimates and the structure of the cluster cores in more detail, we plot <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> against \u03b1, <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-2-1\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-2-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.2.1</a>) and X-ray/BCG offset in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>. There is considerable scatter in all three panels; however, we try to fit a straight-line relation to the data in each case. We obtain a positive correlation between <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> and all of \u03b1, <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> and offset, as shown by the dashed lines in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f9\" data-open=\"f9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 9</a>; however, the <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> versus <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> is the only one of the three with a slope that is statistically distinguishable from flat, with a best fit of <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub>= (1.8 \u00b1 0.3) + (0.63 \u00b1 0.35) log<sub>10</sub>(<em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>)\u2013 i.e. an \u223c2\u03c3 detection of a dependence of <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> on <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680613\" scrollto-destination=\"64680613\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=Yq13kZIj4XxRhaeDSjRpB99e9TatW0dCgjVeiX8CE23HYn~UBB2-IjikATA8b4uA-APYT2S1ncDVR3gOXky6zUyXOTpff42sjrE2IJ1FqkvVUwyvSIT5ROZjvKJ~IL-UvrLnklD~gqSdyIktdcreM5KuLFR5SqliXnwdzB4iD5P3F4qXaAWfFmDyB63e7Uy6moMAZFqsQThdCvsm3daOp3-HjcfHxMpFRW~jrTy5M5LpbkQOy1geA6C0fZ1y-8igZmHCny0t8uzwuf4F6MIY314XQr7QyiSiUR0IvG0L8tMUmX79Yul1AgqOTAZH~xJCGqfDtra5NYGPe3NeYzsm0w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residuals of the MSL/MX relation against the central X-ray slope \u03b1 (left-hand panel), the strong-lensing derived substructure fraction (middle panel) or the offset between the X-ray centre and the BCG (right-hand panel). The red dashed line shows the best-fitting linear relation for each diagram. Symbols are identical to Fig. 8.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680613/mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680613\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=EU3331PKPC5VPDb3Vn2C~trTQwXy7pCmoXj8CrZuPsUSHU7FdzdUhHD9vtMSJvZ2fnsNQAgDp7xtLAmpqqZMlKyat1PTCayxNEz3NFQ90v26n3dEn17QvyhZ77M8amUlXuuFb78pAiGap9ep6TOAxvR4kP2buC2NuAFTkW3Y59NSts5UqX~U0JMue3LLwMn4oU8W6P67666TAMSfzzi-C9zPjHzmfrh4iTVEZAui7-XiWWozYi3MrIakkS~X4B9UC6T7AtBSEo5VW~wSteGkuXD-Hx8qJRC127bZlDlfqtwXUP7~yw-bmK3mlvrIMLZTOQJ6n7R7bh35g3-g9~zvLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680613&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residuals of the <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> relation against the central X-ray slope \u03b1 (left-hand panel), the strong-lensing derived substructure fraction (middle panel) or the offset between the X-ray centre and the BCG (right-hand panel). The red dashed line shows the best-fitting linear relation for each diagram. Symbols are identical to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=Yq13kZIj4XxRhaeDSjRpB99e9TatW0dCgjVeiX8CE23HYn~UBB2-IjikATA8b4uA-APYT2S1ncDVR3gOXky6zUyXOTpff42sjrE2IJ1FqkvVUwyvSIT5ROZjvKJ~IL-UvrLnklD~gqSdyIktdcreM5KuLFR5SqliXnwdzB4iD5P3F4qXaAWfFmDyB63e7Uy6moMAZFqsQThdCvsm3daOp3-HjcfHxMpFRW~jrTy5M5LpbkQOy1geA6C0fZ1y-8igZmHCny0t8uzwuf4F6MIY314XQr7QyiSiUR0IvG0L8tMUmX79Yul1AgqOTAZH~xJCGqfDtra5NYGPe3NeYzsm0w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Residuals of the MSL/MX relation against the central X-ray slope \u03b1 (left-hand panel), the strong-lensing derived substructure fraction (middle panel) or the offset between the X-ray centre and the BCG (right-hand panel). The red dashed line shows the best-fitting linear relation for each diagram. Symbols are identical to Fig. 8.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680613/mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680613\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=EU3331PKPC5VPDb3Vn2C~trTQwXy7pCmoXj8CrZuPsUSHU7FdzdUhHD9vtMSJvZ2fnsNQAgDp7xtLAmpqqZMlKyat1PTCayxNEz3NFQ90v26n3dEn17QvyhZ77M8amUlXuuFb78pAiGap9ep6TOAxvR4kP2buC2NuAFTkW3Y59NSts5UqX~U0JMue3LLwMn4oU8W6P67666TAMSfzzi-C9zPjHzmfrh4iTVEZAui7-XiWWozYi3MrIakkS~X4B9UC6T7AtBSEo5VW~wSteGkuXD-Hx8qJRC127bZlDlfqtwXUP7~yw-bmK3mlvrIMLZTOQJ6n7R7bh35g3-g9~zvLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680613&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Residuals of the <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> relation against the central X-ray slope \u03b1 (left-hand panel), the strong-lensing derived substructure fraction (middle panel) or the offset between the X-ray centre and the BCG (right-hand panel). The red dashed line shows the best-fitting linear relation for each diagram. Symbols are identical to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We interpret this as evidence that the assumption of hydrostatic equilibrium required by the X-ray mass estimates is less reliable in clusters with larger substructure fractions. Specifically, the merging activity signalled by larger substructure fractions may be adding non-hydrostatic pressure support to the Intracluster Medium (ICM) through bulk motions of gas in a manner similar to that identified by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b60\" data-open=\"b60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rasia et al. (2006)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b52\" data-open=\"b52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nagai, Vikhlinin &amp; Kravtsov (2007)</a> at larger radii in simulations.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680615 id=\"64680615\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2>4.2 Cluster substructure, BCG dominance and ellipticity</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680616 id=\"64680616\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2-1>4.2.1 Substructure fractions</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Following Sm05 and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith &amp; Taylor (2008)</a>, we define the substructure fraction <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> as the fraction of the mass within a radius <em>R</em> that is not contained in the BCG and the cluster-scale dark matter halo centred on the BCG. This allows straightforward calculation of <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> from the mass models, and provides an estimate of the fraction of mass that resides in galaxy- and group-scale haloes within the parent cluster. We measure <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> within the same aperture as for <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>, i.e. <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc. At these scales, <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> is stable to small changes in the aperture choice; this stability extends down to <em>R</em>\u2273 100 kpc in most cases. The measurements of <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t7\" data-open=\"t7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith &amp; Taylor (2008)</a> compared the predicted (from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b85\" data-open=\"b85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Taylor &amp; Babul 2005</a>) and observed (from Sm05) <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> distributions, finding a possible excess of clusters with the highest values of <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>. They speculated that, if confirmed, these excesses may be due to X-ray-selected clusters comprising an excess of cool-core and merging clusters with respect to a purely mass-selected sample (the synthetic clusters were selected on mass from Taylor &amp; Babul's model). We return to this distribution in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a> with our enlarged sample of 20 strong-lensing clusters (Sm05 comprises five strong-lensing and five weak-lensing constrained cluster cores). As seen in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f10\" data-open=\"f10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 10</a>, the observed <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> distribution remains noisy with 20 clusters. We repeat the Kolmogorov\u2013Smirnov test of Smith &amp; Taylor, and again obtain an inconclusive result, with the null hypothesis that the observed and synthetic samples are drawn from the same underlying distribution disfavoured at 80 per cent (i.e. 1.3\u03c3) confidence.</p>                        <a id=\"64680619\" scrollto-destination=\"64680619\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=YTxgUDL5QOTav~-ggBSFyhOhEUyQQHy~Ilgf7NvkCShlWLYGktWw3M0IX~AeirlqtXRKSyn8JQ90RB4HMaHUnXEnHO1OXoxyD3UTr2DXc1AEbrYgx-gRqhs6HqEBYdI3blkfkVKzgXh5eZLz-mpQ~g-uRAFMZGbwtUKyEf6kTyJPV5SLrsdTndXuFdMjRS3-Is6HDhFAlkMwT1TVX8zb8YZfRP7nwNv1epiCCLzU-oI8fD061kyWjfsYGSbTC~UQHKH33FJHsV~Dj7glmc-8j~hTb~QiMwHBz6HJnceKlxxKqyWQ~HcE-P~mP3XCZQdcGjrpPPeQTIB0rlo1viutoQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed substructure fraction (solid curve), as determined from the 20 strong-lensing models in the extended sample, compared with the expected distribution (dashed curve) presented in Smith &amp; Taylor (2008). Left-hand diagram: cumulative distribution. Right-hand diagram: differential distribution.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680619/mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=4FIiH5hlHHCBUyWHOVvct7JskFHtbe4InEJt348HWqow4pNkVsGPgPZz5kBB4596eK0fSSEuSnwAc0M4H8oMSSuYkTULxC9DfhgsrY0SGZLcViWU5bZ2unmQII9GW2NHrL8RdND90KBhhvuRohGoJSkQnJHmRue5jOAkNCWbzAiZQ4WauleoNh6y0gXDL9dqfgyEpuTiHIGT~2d53ENrfMs3Y1HwV80SDqlEAQfkWTs6eBBqLvXHEKAaCuklA7fDrpjuBRbaFCRqU1aw4PjjrakAsWQNJSR6uK~aQqd9aF9liKhs1rtdlDahZFgi-JsBlvwmHB9dS7hYf2N6TROaMQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680619&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed substructure fraction (solid curve), as determined from the 20 strong-lensing models in the extended sample, compared with the expected distribution (dashed curve) presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith &amp; Taylor (2008)</a>. Left-hand diagram: cumulative distribution. Right-hand diagram: differential distribution.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=YTxgUDL5QOTav~-ggBSFyhOhEUyQQHy~Ilgf7NvkCShlWLYGktWw3M0IX~AeirlqtXRKSyn8JQ90RB4HMaHUnXEnHO1OXoxyD3UTr2DXc1AEbrYgx-gRqhs6HqEBYdI3blkfkVKzgXh5eZLz-mpQ~g-uRAFMZGbwtUKyEf6kTyJPV5SLrsdTndXuFdMjRS3-Is6HDhFAlkMwT1TVX8zb8YZfRP7nwNv1epiCCLzU-oI8fD061kyWjfsYGSbTC~UQHKH33FJHsV~Dj7glmc-8j~hTb~QiMwHBz6HJnceKlxxKqyWQ~HcE-P~mP3XCZQdcGjrpPPeQTIB0rlo1viutoQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed substructure fraction (solid curve), as determined from the 20 strong-lensing models in the extended sample, compared with the expected distribution (dashed curve) presented in Smith &amp; Taylor (2008). Left-hand diagram: cumulative distribution. Right-hand diagram: differential distribution.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680619/mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=4FIiH5hlHHCBUyWHOVvct7JskFHtbe4InEJt348HWqow4pNkVsGPgPZz5kBB4596eK0fSSEuSnwAc0M4H8oMSSuYkTULxC9DfhgsrY0SGZLcViWU5bZ2unmQII9GW2NHrL8RdND90KBhhvuRohGoJSkQnJHmRue5jOAkNCWbzAiZQ4WauleoNh6y0gXDL9dqfgyEpuTiHIGT~2d53ENrfMs3Y1HwV80SDqlEAQfkWTs6eBBqLvXHEKAaCuklA7fDrpjuBRbaFCRqU1aw4PjjrakAsWQNJSR6uK~aQqd9aF9liKhs1rtdlDahZFgi-JsBlvwmHB9dS7hYf2N6TROaMQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680619&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f10.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed substructure fraction (solid curve), as determined from the 20 strong-lensing models in the extended sample, compared with the expected distribution (dashed curve) presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith &amp; Taylor (2008)</a>. Left-hand diagram: cumulative distribution. Right-hand diagram: differential distribution.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">There is extensive discussion in the literature on the issue of whether cluster\u2013cluster mergers are capable of destroying cool cores (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Poole et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Burns et al. 2008</a>). We have previously addressed this question indirectly through comparisons of \u03b1 and X-ray/BCG offsets in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. (2009a)</a>. Here, we tackle it more directly, by comparing \u03b1 with <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f11\" data-open=\"f11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 11</a>. We fit a relation of the form log<sub>10</sub>(<em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>) =<em>A</em>+<em>B</em> \u03b1 and obtain best-fitting parameters of <em>A</em>= 0.09 \u00b1 0.12 and <em>B</em>= 1.15 \u00b1 0.22. We therefore find a positive correlation at 5\u03c3 significance between <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> and \u03b1, albeit with large scatter. Clusters that host a cool core therefore also have less substructure in their cluster core mass distribution, and vice versa. This supports the connection found in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4-1-3\"></span><a href=\"#ss4-1-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4.1.3</a> between the differing values of <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> for cool-core and non-cool-core clusters, and the positive correlation between the mass ratio and <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>. This result is also strongly suggestive that the cluster\u2013cluster merger activity associated with larger values of <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> plays a role in destroying cool cores. However, the appreciable scatter on this relationship also suggests that the physics is more complicated than a simple one-to-one relationship.</p>                        <a id=\"64680621\" scrollto-destination=\"64680621\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=JD~ulJSgn5MuEbGrhTudFrstSe50Kxh6J4YaiXPHQ4tWWy3fHG9Y7VF2v952xUTQyOUHyRDPf0RH5o8AdCl0VD47PZTCR~M5aXiBKG9ZstOw3e3DDv~a-p15oqIbNudOt~LTbVKWTcSVWnV5Pt-JxvHtTGF6tAAfC7-Vg6M5tFwJ9Hpw6y-loN1Ul0RjwFr6paEyjH9lMwMIqENv-Tk00MLKARSnoWLwwOpuN5eLezZ~bW0m6RRG8wFoKeBTgRijKBUoAlQSu~ut-FKDjwqJd0Dn4F6KmzUyC9RHZJW3RNx4vPYuoDd9XbO6y68WL4xxqaPT2aODu0UcJsSrhelcNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relationship between substructure fraction, fsub, and \u03b1 the slope of the gas density profile at 0.04, r500, as a measure of the strength of cooling in the cluster cores core. Symbols are identical to Fig. 8. Symbols are identical to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation to the data.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f11\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=JD~ulJSgn5MuEbGrhTudFrstSe50Kxh6J4YaiXPHQ4tWWy3fHG9Y7VF2v952xUTQyOUHyRDPf0RH5o8AdCl0VD47PZTCR~M5aXiBKG9ZstOw3e3DDv~a-p15oqIbNudOt~LTbVKWTcSVWnV5Pt-JxvHtTGF6tAAfC7-Vg6M5tFwJ9Hpw6y-loN1Ul0RjwFr6paEyjH9lMwMIqENv-Tk00MLKARSnoWLwwOpuN5eLezZ~bW0m6RRG8wFoKeBTgRijKBUoAlQSu~ut-FKDjwqJd0Dn4F6KmzUyC9RHZJW3RNx4vPYuoDd9XbO6y68WL4xxqaPT2aODu0UcJsSrhelcNA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Relationship between substructure fraction, fsub, and \u03b1 the slope of the gas density profile at 0.04, r500, as a measure of the strength of cooling in the cluster cores core. Symbols are identical to Fig. 8. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation to the data.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680621/mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680621\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=cqHilgdywFuP8Cz3HRZA~HqRxy4NPlZMeb6aXTll0xLb0xVP~Ka1vkqWy4Ozc5fIbc4chXjSAAbHZTzCegk9B8Z9nhmxPti~6sIn2B0P9zcZodLBfRDSrro1MKlQstjffwb8KoBi9FdIs3E3vdG0BaUYEdPy2JgaoDZ7cY0nUVKSI7dVFRce~rDxFhIDLp-MBM7RbEl0C4lRaUVetzZAw2hxF3Gay7lnfecKcleF5ADJRtu6eSWMuHlPkzdzdOehMLNaJivnxaeBBhJoBLeBGMGIldCqJtRFfX1e~3RYKdUS4f9tpHi5xnANKy7WkAazPpYjPBNJ3XUMG9J62vZODQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680621&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f11.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Relationship between substructure fraction, <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>, and \u03b1 the slope of the gas density profile at 0.04, <em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, as a measure of the strength of cooling in the cluster cores core. Symbols are identical to <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f8\" data-open=\"f8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 8</a>. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation to the data.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680622 id=\"64680622\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2-2>4.2.2 BCG dominance</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The dominance of the BCG over the total <em>K</em>-band luminosity of cluster galaxies within cluster cores was investigated by Sm05, who found a roughly monotonic relationship between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu10.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=KRVcB4umMJGNX6OEdydSvaNPwEY6p6Brk2ux8Lz5jdxmqdSJog5DXdLP4fz2QD-sQeKUYW2RFq8BKWVgLrd7QPNR-67WUCrZJ-hk55GDS9HaLerS~t2tS18ycDOr74IREvNi6Cx3M-g4yLaHYjYLloGAIn8o4p1J5Qz3WH9aLulEenUvh5z~XQ~WAhj9Y9fJjnZWROegzkgLG08Nl~sKsJ8K3XUi2xArTpN-GjQObAlXDtAy~qHgMY~fpfR9rJAoeC70~FsvAgGrZ4-t1O1mZQeWk9M1YvBUQ8sh2nGkIUFMVH3MglhcwsAL0WCRuTr7YenfLVSAKcrY-UP6mifNpw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu10.gif\" /></span> and <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> in the sense that more dominant BCGs live in clusters with lower substructure fractions. This has been investigated in more detail recently by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. (2009b)</a> who showed that \u223c8 per cent of 10<sup>15</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub> clusters contain a BCG at least 2 mag brighter than the second-ranked cluster galaxy (\u0394<em>m</em><sub>12</sub> &gt; 2). We build on these results here by comparing substructure in the total mass distribution in the cluster cores with the dominance of the BCGs for our enlarged sample of 20 strong-lensing clusters. We plot <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> versus both the fraction of the cluster <em>K</em>-band luminosity emanating from the BCG and the magnitude gap between the BCG and the second-ranked cluster galaxy in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f12\" data-open=\"f12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 12</a>, with both measured within the same <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc region as <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>. Both plots show an obvious correlation, confirming and extended the results in Sm05. We obtain best-fitting relations of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu11.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=SvHhzLxCWCHWGJotJ8Wa6lM~7Zjd~g6s9o8Q~SYPL6xgVkgErobED5gauSqoGpOUsZLkn1FL1CjnBayJOwtkh-HJNqchG1Be2DpIp~EKGVfWaEQH3GDwzHxakDJHM2otw5no-ALhnptsx-VE3aY-LNvbKbeatUsylfd7TbpdBpLbudFNFsRxVybIypPl5nuWkOFFAzIyjqNw1kG9g-KKnH8t~b2uwXrKdVGlqLeEnzYannSl-IzqLgWMKv2SXrznyb6APu3hf2MiVetunYtRWu3bWNf3c22NqqPHatmXOxUSOSSoy4SQazp427skoqYrZNRzXSUV1SiDYNfa~1DWRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu11.gif\" /></span> and log<sub>10</sub>(<em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>) =\u22120.53\u0394<em>m</em><sub>12</sub>\u2212 0.07, both relations having a dispersion of \u03c3\u223c 0.3 dex.</p>                        <a id=\"64680624\" scrollto-destination=\"64680624\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=NZjS5CqYeqdJ1w3cYoFl0dSs4Zt21b0n55Gc7nxzXMJSMmMvsT3dqg-Olid~SrcLh~Il7T0YLP8W2XZkw-nWrsaQ1aoNhcpzVw3FWO4GR51GMTddHCzYZtd0FIbThv4P5Q0DUswZaRMAJBCjupTM08UQjIoyNCQQ3W8eYnMyy0GmR-IdekUZMYFKj9N16UuAzXeasYcqaKZm5S9~NTRmKlvciHxsg8L9SHcxXsFt6h-tuqiPNx1S5hpKB9ieb2iEBCuSLj3XauChgjIwdRvgmRK754nWBSQPMWGRbDYQkqi4bvX4iOrxv0ynOdSvSmCMHL1G~ySe2c80TjC-SaP~Cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Substructure fraction versus indicators of BCG dominance: fraction of the cluster core K-band luminosity that emanates from the BCG (left-hand panel) and the magnitude gap between the BCG and the second-ranked cluster galaxy (right-hand panel). Filled symbols are the new clusters and open symbols are from the extended sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680624/mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=UN4v5OnnTtWpTLWUMFqtyLNa-0GMeEyLlT3mCm33qEDARvi1l8bux58zIGxwFGSIMIIvQFrD451XZurB7bXFE4-WbYgihUGVX4v1PBexyb7WEVNvoTLTC7npN0lku8Lr2b7Dsv86Gwa0rr1RDumUgmTLFflfa77Ee2qcQ2A7Cbinl0pNo2RyTRuCz5JVOl~3tZroMIYu~VvH0x0VzfqeD7PNf7celFMJiDUuuyqnCI3EPbKj6jLw3yauMJSiBRGAdKANzwkvrY3skOOa1HVxwYrK74nG-AncmlPvEgqvIkEdwCuLL95Tv38h6kLZPalmzL0PTDqOjqxpwIUi-uiB-w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680624&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Substructure fraction versus indicators of BCG dominance: fraction of the cluster core <em>K</em>-band luminosity that emanates from the BCG (left-hand panel) and the magnitude gap between the BCG and the second-ranked cluster galaxy (right-hand panel). Filled symbols are the new clusters and open symbols are from the extended sample.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f12\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 12</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=NZjS5CqYeqdJ1w3cYoFl0dSs4Zt21b0n55Gc7nxzXMJSMmMvsT3dqg-Olid~SrcLh~Il7T0YLP8W2XZkw-nWrsaQ1aoNhcpzVw3FWO4GR51GMTddHCzYZtd0FIbThv4P5Q0DUswZaRMAJBCjupTM08UQjIoyNCQQ3W8eYnMyy0GmR-IdekUZMYFKj9N16UuAzXeasYcqaKZm5S9~NTRmKlvciHxsg8L9SHcxXsFt6h-tuqiPNx1S5hpKB9ieb2iEBCuSLj3XauChgjIwdRvgmRK754nWBSQPMWGRbDYQkqi4bvX4iOrxv0ynOdSvSmCMHL1G~ySe2c80TjC-SaP~Cw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Substructure fraction versus indicators of BCG dominance: fraction of the cluster core K-band luminosity that emanates from the BCG (left-hand panel) and the magnitude gap between the BCG and the second-ranked cluster galaxy (right-hand panel). Filled symbols are the new clusters and open symbols are from the extended sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680624/mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=UN4v5OnnTtWpTLWUMFqtyLNa-0GMeEyLlT3mCm33qEDARvi1l8bux58zIGxwFGSIMIIvQFrD451XZurB7bXFE4-WbYgihUGVX4v1PBexyb7WEVNvoTLTC7npN0lku8Lr2b7Dsv86Gwa0rr1RDumUgmTLFflfa77Ee2qcQ2A7Cbinl0pNo2RyTRuCz5JVOl~3tZroMIYu~VvH0x0VzfqeD7PNf7celFMJiDUuuyqnCI3EPbKj6jLw3yauMJSiBRGAdKANzwkvrY3skOOa1HVxwYrK74nG-AncmlPvEgqvIkEdwCuLL95Tv38h6kLZPalmzL0PTDqOjqxpwIUi-uiB-w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680624&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f12.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Substructure fraction versus indicators of BCG dominance: fraction of the cluster core <em>K</em>-band luminosity that emanates from the BCG (left-hand panel) and the magnitude gap between the BCG and the second-ranked cluster galaxy (right-hand panel). Filled symbols are the new clusters and open symbols are from the extended sample.</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680625 id=\"64680625\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss4-2-3>4.2.3 Cluster ellipticity</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have measured the two-dimensional ellipticity and orientation of each cluster core mass distribution (<em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc) by fitting elliptical mass contours with the <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> routine <span class=\"small-caps\">ellipse</span> to the projected mass maps based on the mass models (see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2009</a>). We kept the centre of the ellipses fixed at the peak of the mass map and let the ellipticity <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu12.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=ga7ZiM9C-KTGnHPeeXxVqmF8coiL5H3vStWao7H7UcihJB3C0UHxBHaAdMTBMrXYgIgbVyEeVd6cIUHeRZ0BhGKesvQWYUQ9b28p7LDNvP2i3fhs~ArIeiEAIjcCv3yGI6DxLuskcmFz0V8m8o-SpNngmmC4wOs9y2PF2ipwUYbpGXDm55DGYtHzliGrt1N9RthDvRcGffazN8DTJsfFIarFZP~3F~lYIFaeIBDfS-WS91O6YntdaySEa~Zff3AJA3SlpeQbs4j8JgpO3cgqJBh3fEfhuj6uraTkb77j-eqB6ZLK5TqGryNKgOAEJx2b2slPCaExhm9nBdHE-tVMPA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu12.gif\" /></span> and position angle \u03c6<sub>2D</sub>(<em>a</em>) vary as free parameters with the semimajor axis <em>a</em>. The resulting ellipticities are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t7\" data-open=\"t7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 7</a>, and the distribution is plotted in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f13\" data-open=\"f13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 13</a>. We also show in this figure the predicted distributions from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a>, both for the underlying mass-selected cluster population and for clusters with the largest Einstein radii. Oguri &amp; Blandford interpreted the difference between these two distributions, with the latter peaking at smaller ellipticities than the former, as implying that the major axis of the three-dimensional mass distributions of strong-lensing clusters are more likely to be closely aligned with our line of sight through the clusters. Strong-lensing clusters are therefore expected to be rounder in the sky than non-strong-lensing clusters.</p>                        <a id=\"64680627\" scrollto-destination=\"64680627\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=GlA7jEjgsLDHoaa2EBp35AHSXqNrimRPMG8PU0IxMI6DusGSP5GklrLvsNyf7wzlk8GvbPl-pCqfvr1o1Ff7PzkAZTcyx47k6kkqeCVVWiQoOF2UKbMrf9nLpxITNN8FpvW8TQpFsw8McZXY8-L4uiHIdodfiEO7xpKIDR9J8VPxjJQUqrHUB1SAAd-sF1nFGISAyzfkbT1-3y3pJtpLmhzAWGgwy3CedV9LpWDCYMPn1BJZnviv6-rXiEWbTUoxTe2ebCeccMtoOt35OeWAhBlTCdPqikx7Vp0dZypILdk9~G8bEaBfZtElF3WBGBleYnxfDju0Ps5xVfDE-NNk1Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed distribution of two-dimensional ellipticities (red solid histogram) compared with predictions from simulations by Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009), for an unbiased cluster population (black dashed histogram) and a cluster population producing the largest Einstein radii (black dotted histogram). The observed peak at e2D\u2243 0.65 is dominated by A 1201 and A 521, the two clusters with the smallest Einstein radii (red dot\u2013dashed histogram). The red solid curve shows the Gaussian fit to the probability distribution.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680627/mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680627\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=Qwq~rqar~iF~quWMqBoreJ30gt3dmbUmwj6NI1pfbeegFnteDrmlucg70w9opbqVua2AELf1yjcQSteWQhiX~UhYiBH4SD0eeoGBKoc1GvUQBa-F8YeuiLqVijfvpWoasw~xTdcmWLhLZiojfkMDHbPw9DrxcrBXgKmAlk24QjkwLuxHVLOVx-~wqwEf8vGZR9m7K~dc4azzr6RIel8hXVpKW3OXS-TMYFgqMgN1BBsHAo~n-Qk3ZPyDpsOtsWORoDCDsnzm6pMU75S7pcosX~F5S9PFBGcyzyacHcs7b6Q-83rKB49ORjRSoEbrBjoGgzPdeEQYq~CKjNcKHCvkHw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680627&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed distribution of two-dimensional ellipticities (red solid histogram) compared with predictions from simulations by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a>, for an unbiased cluster population (black dashed histogram) and a cluster population producing the largest Einstein radii (black dotted histogram). The observed peak at <em>e</em><sub>2D</sub>\u2243 0.65 is dominated by A 1201 and A 521, the two clusters with the smallest Einstein radii (red dot\u2013dashed histogram). The red solid curve shows the Gaussian fit to the probability distribution.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f13\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 13</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=GlA7jEjgsLDHoaa2EBp35AHSXqNrimRPMG8PU0IxMI6DusGSP5GklrLvsNyf7wzlk8GvbPl-pCqfvr1o1Ff7PzkAZTcyx47k6kkqeCVVWiQoOF2UKbMrf9nLpxITNN8FpvW8TQpFsw8McZXY8-L4uiHIdodfiEO7xpKIDR9J8VPxjJQUqrHUB1SAAd-sF1nFGISAyzfkbT1-3y3pJtpLmhzAWGgwy3CedV9LpWDCYMPn1BJZnviv6-rXiEWbTUoxTe2ebCeccMtoOt35OeWAhBlTCdPqikx7Vp0dZypILdk9~G8bEaBfZtElF3WBGBleYnxfDju0Ps5xVfDE-NNk1Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Observed distribution of two-dimensional ellipticities (red solid histogram) compared with predictions from simulations by Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009), for an unbiased cluster population (black dashed histogram) and a cluster population producing the largest Einstein radii (black dotted histogram). The observed peak at e2D\u2243 0.65 is dominated by A 1201 and A 521, the two clusters with the smallest Einstein radii (red dot\u2013dashed histogram). The red solid curve shows the Gaussian fit to the probability distribution.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680627/mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680627\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&Signature=Qwq~rqar~iF~quWMqBoreJ30gt3dmbUmwj6NI1pfbeegFnteDrmlucg70w9opbqVua2AELf1yjcQSteWQhiX~UhYiBH4SD0eeoGBKoc1GvUQBa-F8YeuiLqVijfvpWoasw~xTdcmWLhLZiojfkMDHbPw9DrxcrBXgKmAlk24QjkwLuxHVLOVx-~wqwEf8vGZR9m7K~dc4azzr6RIel8hXVpKW3OXS-TMYFgqMgN1BBsHAo~n-Qk3ZPyDpsOtsWORoDCDsnzm6pMU75S7pcosX~F5S9PFBGcyzyacHcs7b6Q-83rKB49ORjRSoEbrBjoGgzPdeEQYq~CKjNcKHCvkHw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=64680627&ar=3101555&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f13.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed distribution of two-dimensional ellipticities (red solid histogram) compared with predictions from simulations by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b56\" data-open=\"b56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oguri &amp; Blandford (2009)</a>, for an unbiased cluster population (black dashed histogram) and a cluster population producing the largest Einstein radii (black dotted histogram). The observed peak at <em>e</em><sub>2D</sub>\u2243 0.65 is dominated by A 1201 and A 521, the two clusters with the smallest Einstein radii (red dot\u2013dashed histogram). The red solid curve shows the Gaussian fit to the probability distribution.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our observed distribution agrees better with the predicted distribution of large Einstein radii clusters than with the mass-selected population; however, we detect a peak at <em>e</em><sub>2D</sub>\u2243 0.65. This peak contains A 521 and A 1201, the two clusters in our sample with the smallest Einstein radii, demonstrating that clusters with small Einstein radii can still be strong-lensing clusters if background galaxies are fortuitously aligned. We therefore exclude these two clusters from the observed distribution and fit a normal distribution to the other 18 clusters, obtaining \u3008<em>e</em><sub>2D</sub>\u3009= 0.34 \u00b1 0.14.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680629 id=\"64680629\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss5>5 SUMMARY AND DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented a strong-lensing analysis of 20 massive galaxy clusters from the X-ray-selected LoCuSS sample, all of which contain at least one spectroscopically confirmed multiple-image background galaxy. 10 of the sample are new strong-lensing clusters for which we present the first detailed parametric lens models based on new spectroscopic redshift measurements at the Keck-I telescope. All of the clusters are well described by a parametric mass distribution containing one or several cluster-scale dark matter haloes centred on the brightest peaks of the cluster <em>K</em>-band light. We used our parametric models to compute maps of the mass distribution in the cluster cores, and thus to measure the projected mass and fraction of that mass associated with substructures within <em>R</em>\u2264 250 kpc. We have compared these measurements with observations of the baryons within the clusters, employing X-ray and <em>K</em>-band data to probe the intracluster medium and evolved stars, respectively. Our main results are summarized below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Einstein radius for a typical source redshift of <em>z</em>= 2 spans 4 arcsec \u2264\u03b8<sub>E</sub>(<em>z</em>= 2) \u2264 47 arcsec and is lognormally distributed, peaking at \u3008log<sub>10</sub>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u3009= 1.16 \u00b1 0.28, where the uncertainty is width of the distribution. Famous clusters with a large Einstein radius, A 1689 and A 1703, are thus \u2018outliers\u2019 at 2\u03c3 and 1.5\u03c3 above the mean, respectively. We also compare the observed distribution with that predicted from the Millennium Simulation, and find that the peak of the predicted distribution lies at \u223c5 arcsec, i.e. \u223c1.7\u03c3 below that of the observed distribution.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u03b8<sub>E</sub>(<em>z</em>= 2) is correlated with <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>(<em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc), the projected mass of the cluster core obtained from the strong-lens models. We find that \u2018disturbed\u2019 clusters, i.e. those with an offset between the centroid of their X-ray emission and the optical centroid of their BCG of &gt;0.01<em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, typically lie below the best-fitting \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u2212<em>M</em><sub>SL</sub> relation. We interpret this as arising from a combination of (i) cluster\u2013cluster mergers (assumed to be responsible for the X-ray/BCG offset) acting to soften the cluster density profile, and thus reduce \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, and (ii) an orientation effect, i.e. that the major axis of disturbed clusters tends to be closer to orthogonal to the line of sight through the cluster, whilst undisturbed clusters tend to have their major axis parallel with the line of sight.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ratio of strong-lensing-based and X-ray-based projected cluster mass measurements within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc is measured to be <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub>= 1.3, discrepant with unity at 3\u03c3. This X-ray/lensing mass discrepancy depends on the structure of the cluster core \u2013 we detect a positive correlation between <em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub> and the fraction of cluster mass associated with substructures within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc, <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>, at 2\u03c3 significance. We interpret this as evidence that the cluster\u2013cluster merger activity associated with cluster substructure is responsible for departures from hydrostatic equilibrium.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The substructure fraction, <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub>, is also correlated with \u03b1, the slope of the logarithmic gas density profile at 0.04<em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, in the sense that clusters with steeper (more negative \u03b1) gas density profiles have smaller values of <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> and vice versa. The gas density profile slope is used as an indicator of the strength of cooling in the intracluster medium, the steepest slopes (\u03b1\u2272 0.85) being identified as \u2018cool-core clusters\u2019. This direct empirical relationship between \u03b1 and <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> implies a connection between the cluster\u2013cluster mergers and the strength of cooling in cluster cores.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also find a strong correlation between <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> and the dominance of the BCG in the sense that clusters with more substructure have less dominant BCGs. This suggests that measures of BCG dominance, including the luminosity gap statistic (difference between the magnitudes of the first- and second-ranked galaxies), may be a useful probe of cluster substructure.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of cluster core ellipticities, measured from the mass maps that are in turn computed from the parametric lens models, are consistent with the predicted ellipticity distribution of strong-lensing clusters.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">This is the largest published sample of strong-lensing clusters to date \u2013 a four times increase in sample size from Sm05. Overall, our empirical results are consistent with those of Smith et al. in that a straightforward interpretation is that cluster\u2013cluster mergers play a prominent role in shaping the observed properties of cluster cores. This is most striking in the X-ray/lensing comparisons, i.e. significant detection of a 30 per cent X-ray/lensing mass discrepancy and a dependence of this discrepancy on structure of the cluster core. This is underlined by the correlation between <em>f</em><sub>sub</sub> and \u03b1\u2013 implying that cluster\u2013cluster mergers both cause departures from hydrostatic equilibrium and play a role in moderating the cooling of gas in cluster cores. This latter point remains controversial (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b15\" data-open=\"b15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Burns et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b59\" data-open=\"b59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Poole et al. 2008</a>), and we caution that the distribution of formation epochs and other physical processes such as pre-heating may ultimately modify our simplistic interpretation.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We also note that the clusters with the largest Einstein radii in our sample (A 1689 and A 1703) are \u22722\u03c3 above the mean of the best-fitting lognormal distribution, implying that \u223c2 \u2212 7 per cent of larger samples will contain comparable clusters. We also speculate that the \u223c1.7\u03c3 discrepancy between the peak of the observed and predicted Einstein radius distributions may be in part attributable to the presence of baryons in the observed universe, in contrast to the dark matter only simulations on which the prediction is based. Certainly, the discrepancy is likely overestimated because of the current computational limitations on numerical simulations, namely that even the most advanced simulations such as the Millennium simulation do not embrace sufficient volume at sufficient numerical resolution to contain a representative sample of the most massive strong-lensing clusters. In summary, we find no compelling evidence from our statistical analysis of a sample of strong-lensing clusters to support recent claims that clusters with large Einstein radii present a challenge to the CDM paradigm (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b12\" data-open=\"b12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst &amp; Barkana 2008</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This article has concentrated on clusters observable from Mauna Kea with the Keck-I telescope. In future, we will expand this sample to include southern clusters that we have also observed with <em>HST</em> and followed up spectroscopically with VLT and Gemini-S (May et al., in preparation). Similar studies of clusters at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.3 from the Massive Cluster Survey (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b21\" data-open=\"b21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling, Edge &amp; Henry 2001</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b22\" data-open=\"b22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 2007</a>) will allow evolution in the properties of cluster cores to be probed (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b81\" data-open=\"b81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009a</a>; Richard et al., in preparation). Within LoCuSS, future work will include combining these strong lens models with our recently published weak-lensing analysis of Subaru observations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2009</a>) \u2013 this will allow a detailed investigation of the structure of the cluster mass distributions across a wide range of physical scales. The well-constrained lens models presented here are also well suited to be utilized in gravitational telescope searches for very high redshift galaxies (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b46\" data-open=\"b46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maizy et al. 2009</a>), following, for example, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b40\" data-open=\"b40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. (2004)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b61\" data-open=\"b61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2006)</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b63\" data-open=\"b63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2008)</a> and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b10\" data-open=\"b10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bouwens et al. (2009)</a>. Finally, we have presented optical spectra of lensed background galaxies at <em>z</em>\u223c 1\u20134, which are magnified by 1\u20134 mag from strong lensing. These sources are well suited for further high-resolution spectroscopic follow-up, such as near-infrared IFU observations (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b84\" data-open=\"b84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Swinbank et al. 2009</a>).</p><div content-id=\"fn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Publicly available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.oamp.fr/cosmology/lenstool\" target=\"_blank\">http://www.oamp.fr/cosmology/lenstool</a>.</p></div></span></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank our colleagues in the LoCuSS collaborations for much support, encouragement and help. We acknowledge useful discussions with Andrew Newman, Masmune Oguri, Arif Babul, Giovanni Covone, Timothy James, Alastair Edge and Ian Smail. We are grateful for Matt Lehnert, Christian Tapken and Nicole Nesvadba for their spectroscopic measurement of one of the systems. Mark Sullivan kindly observed long-slit data on A 611 for us. JR acknowledges support from an EU Marie-Curie fellowship. GPS acknowledges support from the Royal Society and STFC. JPK acknowledges support from the CNRS, from the Agence Nationale de la Recherche grant ANR-06-BLAN-0067 and from the French\u2013Israelian collaboration project07-AST-F9. AJRS acknowledges support from STFC. ML acknowledges the Centre National d' Etudes Spatiales for their support. The Dark Cosmology Centre is funded by the Danish National Research Foundation. Results are partially based on observations made with the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em> and the Keck telescope.The authors recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Mauna Kea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680640 id=\"64680640\" class=\"backreferences-title js-splitscreen-backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list js-splitview-ref-list\"><div content-id=\"b1\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b1\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b1\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b1\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Albrecht</div> <div class=\"given-names\">A.</div></div></span> <em>et al.</em>, <div class=\"year\">2006</div>, preprint (0609591)</p></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b2\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b2\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b2\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b2\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b2\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b2\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Allen</div> <div class=\"given-names\">S. Cambridge Univ. Press, Cambridge, p. <div class=\"fpage\">215</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"google-scholar-ref-link\"><a class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1051/0004-6361:20034484\" </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"b9\" class=\"js-splitview-ref-item\" data-legacy-id=\"b9\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-b9\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-b9\" data-id=\"\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-b9\" class=\"ref-content \" data-id=\"b9\"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bonamente</div> <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div> <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Joy</div> <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></div> <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">LaRoque</div> <div class=\"given-names\">S. J.</div></div> <div class=\"name\"><div class=\"surname\">Carlstrom</div> <div class=\"given-names\">J. js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=ss10>APPENDIX B: BEST-FITTING PARAMETERS OF OTHER MASS MODELS</h3>\r\n                        <a id=\"64680646\" scrollto-destination=\"64680646\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t9\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t9\" data-id=\"t9\"><span class=\"label\">Table B1</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Best-fitting parameters of the mass models. For each mass component, we give the centre, ellipticity, orientation, core and cut radii, as well as central velocity dispersion of the dPIE profile. The following column gives the image plane rms of this model.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Comp.<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u0394\u03b1 (arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n \u00b1 111\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>L* gal\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>[0.15]\u00a0</td><td>2.1 \u00b1 15.6\u00a0</td><td>264 \u00b1 0.5\u00a0</td><td>294.8 \u00b1 24.5\u00a0</td><td>633 \u00b1 2\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>PERT1\u00a0</td><td>[46.9]\u00a0</td><td>[12.8]\u00a0</td><td>0.35 \u00b1 0.09\u00a0</td><td>143.7       </a></div></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n                    <h2 class=\"authorNotes-section-title\" id=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\" scrollto-destination=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\">Author notes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \r\n    </div>\r\n    <div                    <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"f-dropdown\" data-dropdown-content aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"article-content\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Article contents</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n\r\n\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-cite js-item-cite\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\r\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button at-CiteButton\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal>\r\n    <i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i>\r\n    <span>Cite</span>\r\n</a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal js-citation-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Johan Richard, Graham P. Smith, Jean-Paul Kneib, Richard S. Ellis, A. J. R. Sanderson, L. Pei, T. A. Targett, D. J. Sand, A. M. Swinbank, H. Dannerbauer, P. Mazzotta, M. Limousin, E. Egami, E. Jullo, V. Hamilton-Morris, S. M. Moran,  LoCuSS: first results from strong-lensing analysis of 20 massive galaxy clusters at <em>z</em>= 0.2, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 404, Issue 1, May 2010,    </div>\r\n    \r\n    <div class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-nav-dropdown\">\r\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n\r\n<div class=\"navbar\">\r\n    <div class=\"center-inner-row\">\r\n        <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\"
