       <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680487 id=\"64680487\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a statistical analysis of a sample of 20 strong lensing clusters drawn from the Local Cluster Substructure Survey, based on high-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> imaging of the cluster cores and follow-up spectroscopic observations using the Keck-I telescope. We use detailed parametrized models of the mass distribution in the cluster cores, to measure the total cluster mass and fraction of that mass associated with substructures within <em>R</em>\u2264 250 kpc. These measurements are compared with the distribution of baryons in the cores, as traced by the old stellar populations and the X-ray emitting intracluster medium. Our main results include: (i) the distribution of Einstein radii is lognormal, with a peak and 1\u03c3 width of \u3008log<sub>10</sub>\u03b8<sub>E</sub>(<em>z</em>= 2)\u3009= 1.16 \u00b1 0.28; (ii) we detect an X-ray/lensing mass discrepancy of \u3008<em>M</em><sub>SL</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>X</sub>\u3009= 1.3 at 3\u03c3 significance \u2013 clusters with larger substructure fractions displaying greater mass discrepancies, and thus greater departures from hydrostatic equilibrium and (iii) cluster substructure fraction is also correlated with the slope of the gas density profile on small scales, implying a connection between cluster\u2013cluster mergers and gas cooling. Overall our results are consistent with the view that cluster\u2013cluster mergers play a prominent role in shaping the properties of cluster cores, in particular causing departures from hydrostatic equilibrium, and possibly disturbing cool cores. Our results do not support recent claims that large Einstein radius clusters present a challenge to the cold dark matter paradigm.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing&quot;\">gravitational lensing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: clusters: general&quot;\">galaxies: clusters: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680489 id=\"64680489\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The evolution of galaxy clusters with cosmic time is an important cosmological probe, as it traces the gravitational growth of dark matter on large scales. In particular, the cluster mass function can be directly tested against cosmological models, as it is related to fundamental parameters such as the matter density \u03a9<sub>m</sub>, the normalization of the power spectrum \u03c3<sub>8</sub> (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b72\" data-open=\"b72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Schuecker et al. 2003</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b79\" data-open=\"b79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2003</a>) and the dark energy equation of state parameter <em>w</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Commonly used probes of the mass of clusters at <em>z</em>\u223c 0.1\u20130.5 include the <em>K</em>-band luminosity (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lin et al. 2006</a>), X-ray luminosity and temperature (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b87\" data-open=\"b87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vikhlinin et al. 2006</a>), Sunayev\u2013Zeldovich effect (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b51\" data-open=\"b51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Nagai 2006</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b9\" data-open=\"b9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bonamente et al. 2008</a>), cluster kinematics (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b7\" data-open=\"b7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Blindert et al. 2004</a>) and gravitational lensing (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b80\" data-open=\"b80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2005</a>, hereafter Sm05; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bardeau et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2009</a>). Systematic errors in these various mass probes can be calibrated by an intercomparison of results from the various methods. The pursuit of the most robust calibrations based on low-redshift cluster samples is essential to achieve reliable results from future studies at higher redshift, and to control systematic uncertainties in cosmological experiments (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b1\" data-open=\"b1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Albrecht et al. 2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing plays a central role in this effort, as it does not rely on assumptions about the symmetry or equilibrium properties of the cluster mass distribution, although parametrized lensed model implicitly assume, for instance, elliptical symmetry. Indeed, the highest quality measurements of the dark matter mass and substructure in low-redshift clusters have been obtained through the combination of strong and weak gravitational lensing. The identification of background galaxies forming strong lensing arcs in cluster cores is a direct measurement of the enclosed mass within the Einstein radius \u03b8<sub>E</sub>, providing an accurate normalization of cluster mass models both in the core, and extending to larger radii (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b38\" data-open=\"b38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 2003</a>). The main caveats on lensing studies are that the lensing signal is sensitive to the mass distribution projected along the line of sight through the cluster, that the commonly used parametric models must by design assume a parametric form of the mass distribution and that gravitational lensing may prove to be impractical in samples of more distant (<em>z</em> &gt; 1) cluster samples that are starting to be discovered (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b65\" data-open=\"b65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Rosati et al. 1999</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b41\" data-open=\"b41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kurk et al. 2009</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Early joint lensing/X-ray cluster studies identified large discrepancies between total cluster masses obtained from the two methods (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b50\" data-open=\"b50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Miralda-Escude &amp; Babul 1995</a>). These discrepancies were subsequently eliminated, albeit within quite large uncertainties, in cool-core clusters provided that a two-phase gas model was used (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b2\" data-open=\"b2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Allen 1998</a>; see also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b74\" data-open=\"b74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smail et al. 1997</a>). At a similar time, <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) data started to become available for some clusters, allowing more precise strong-lensing models to be constructed (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. 1996</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b86\" data-open=\"b86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Tyson, Kochanski &amp; dell'Antonio 1998</a>). More recent strong lensing studies of cluster mass distributions have generally continued to concentrate on detailed studies of spectacular individual strong lensing clusters based on deep multifilter <em>HST</em> observations (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b13\" data-open=\"b13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Broadhurst et al. 2005</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b43\" data-open=\"b43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Limousin et al. 2007b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b64\" data-open=\"b64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. 2009</a>). The interpretation of results from such studies, e.g. size of Einstein radii and shape of density profile, in the context of the general cluster population is inevitably problematic.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In contrast, Sm05 studied 10 X-ray selected clusters (<em>L</em><sub><em>X</em>,0.2\u22122.4 keV</sub> &gt; 4.1 \u00d7 10<sup>44</sup> erg s<sup>\u22121</sup>) at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2 as a first step towards building large statistical samples of strong lensing clusters. Sm05 combined strong- and weak-lensing constraints from moderate-depth <em>HST</em> observations with X-ray spectro-imaging from <em>Chandra</em>, and near-infrared photometry of cluster galaxies from United Kingdom Infrared Telescope. The main results included the first mass\u2013observable scaling relations to employ lensing-based mass measurements for a well-defined sample; the only previous example employed a compilation of six clusters from the literature (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b33\" data-open=\"b33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hjorth, Oukbir &amp; van Kampen 1998</a>). The main limiting factor on Sm05's results were the small sample size, with just five of the 10 clusters containing spectroscopically confirmed strongly lensed galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Local Cluster Substructure Survey (LoCuSS, PI: G. P. Smith) is an all-sky systematic survey of 165 X-ray luminous clusters at 0.15 &lt; <em>z</em> &lt; 0.30 selected from the <em>ROSAT</em> All-sky Survey catalogues (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ebeling et al. 1998</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b20\" data-open=\"b20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b8\" data-open=\"b8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">B\u00f6hringer et al. 2004</a>). In addition to seeking to improve the statistical precision by enlarging the sample size of studies such as Sm05 and <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b4\" data-open=\"b4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bardeau et al. (2007)</a>, LoCuSS aims to incorporate new constraints on cluster baryons, most notably from observations of the Sunyaev\u2013Zeldovich effect (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b16\" data-open=\"b16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Carlstrom, Holder &amp; Reese 2002</a>) to deliver a definitive local calibration of mass\u2013observable scaling relations that will be useful for cluster cosmology, interpretation of high-redshift cluster samples and probing the physics of gas heating and cooling in merging clusters at low redshift. More generally, LoCuSS aims to constrain the scatter in the baryonic properties of the local cluster population and to correlate the scatter with the recent hierarchical assembly history of the clusters, the latter being constrained by the lensing-based mass maps (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b76\" data-open=\"b76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith &amp; Taylor 2008</a>). A wide variety of studies are therefore underway, including wide-field weak-lensing analysis with Suprime-Cam on Subaru (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b57\" data-open=\"b57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Okabe et al. 2009</a>), the first lensing-based mass\u2013<em>Y<sub>SZ</sub></em> relation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b47\" data-open=\"b47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Marrone et al. 2009</a>), and multiwavelength studies supported by space-based [<em>HST</em>, <em>Herschel</em>, <em>Chandra</em>, Galaxy Evolution Explorer (GALEX), <em>Spitzer</em>] as well as ground-based [Keck, Very Large Telescope (VLT), Gemini, Multiple Mirror Telescope (MMT), Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO), Kitt Peak National Observatory (KPNO), Palomar] facilities (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b91\" data-open=\"b91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Zhang et al. 2008</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b29\" data-open=\"b29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Haines et al. 2009a</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b30\" data-open=\"b30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Haines et al. 2009b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson, O'Sullivan &amp; Ponman 2009b</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b82\" data-open=\"b82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Smith et al. 2009b</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper presents a four-fold increase in the number of clusters with spectroscopically confirmed strong lensing clusters on Sm05. Such constraints remain critical within the overall context of the studies outlined above because strong-lensing offers precise constraints on the mass distribution in cluster cores (<em>R</em>\u223c 100 kpc) which for example provide an invaluable constraint on small scales when trying to measure the shape of cluster density profiles in conjunction with wide-field weak-lensing data from Subaru. We compare the details of the central mass distributions (integrated mass and substructure fraction) obtained from the strong-lensing constraints with near-infrared and X-ray probes of the cluster baryons. We describe the data in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2\"></span><a href=\"#ss2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2</a>, and present the strong-lensing analysis and models in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3\"></span><a href=\"#ss3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3</a>. The main results on the mass and structure of the cluster cores are presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a> and summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss5\"></span><a href=\"#ss5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 5</a>. Throughout the paper, we use magnitudes quoted in the AB system, and a standard \u039b cold dark matter (\u039bCDM) model with \u03a9<sub>m</sub>= 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>= 0.7, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>= 70 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, whenever necessary. In this cosmology, 1 arcsec is equivalent to 3.3 kpc at <em>z</em>= 0.2. We adopt the definition <em>e</em>= 1 \u2212<em>b</em>/<em>a</em> of the ellipticity, where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are the semimajor and semiminor axis of the ellipse, respectively.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=64680497 id=\"64680497\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2>2 OBSERVATIONS AND DATA REDUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present here the cluster sample and the relevant data sets used in our study. The strong lensing analysis relies on two main ingredients: (i) the identification of multiple-image systems and (ii) measurements of their spectroscopic redshifts. The former relies on high-angular-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging, while the latter is carried out using sensitive optical multi-object spectrographs on large aperture ground-based telescopes, in this case Low Resolution Imager and Spectrograph (LRIS) on the Keck-I 10-m telescope. We also use near-infrared photometry to select likely cluster galaxies based on the prominent red sequence of cluster galaxies in the <em>J</em>\u2212<em>K</em>/<em>K</em> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams, that is largely insensitive to spectral type at <em>z</em>\u2243 0.2. These photometric catalogues are also used in the paper during the construction of the lens models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>). Finally, we summarize the analysis of X-ray data available for the majority of these clusters, and which we latter use as a comparison with the strong-lensing results (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss4\"></span><a href=\"#ss4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 4</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680499 id=\"64680499\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-1>2.1 Cluster sample</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The sample in this article comprises the 10 clusters that we have spectroscopically confirmed as strong lenses during our Keck observing campaign 2004\u20132008 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>), plus a further 10 clusters within the LoCuSS sample that have been previously published (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t2\" data-open=\"t2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 2</a>). To qualify for observations with Keck, a cluster must have been previously imaged with <em>HST</em> (79 clusters), and lie at \u03b4 &gt; \u221225\u00b0. We note that some of the clusters with new strong-lensing models had previously been identified as candidate strong-lensing clusters.</p>                        <a id=\"64680501\" scrollto-destination=\"64680501\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t1\" (2007)</a>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2219\u00a0</td><td>250.082 380\u00a0</td><td>46.711 561\u00a0</td><td>0.2281\u00a0</td><td>Sm05\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2390\u00a0</td><td>328.403 290\u00a0</td><td>17.695 740\u00a0</td><td>0.2329\u00a0</td><td>Jullo, PhD thesis\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2667\u00a0</td><td>357.914 125\u00a0</td><td>\u221226.084 375\u00a0</td><td>0.2264\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Covone et al. (2006)</a>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/64680502\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t2\" data-id=\"t2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extended sample of 10 previously published spectroscopically confirmed strong-lensing LoCuSS clusters.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b1<sub>BCG</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<sub>BCG</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Strong-lensing reference<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A 68\u00a0</td><td>9.278 626\u00a0</td><td>9.156 722\u00a0</td><td>0.2546\u00a0</td><td>Sm05; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b62\" data-open=\"b62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Richard et al. (2009)</a>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2218\u00a0</td><td>248.954 604\u00a0</td><td>66.212 242\u00a0</td><td>0.1710\u00a0</td><td>Sm05; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b39\" data-open=\"b39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kneib et al. (1996)</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b24\" data-open=\"b24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et al. (2007)</a>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2219\u00a0</td><td>250.082 380\u00a0</td><td>46.711 561\u00a0</td><td>0.2281\u00a0</td><td>Sm05\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2390\u00a0</td><td>328.403 290\u00a0</td><td>17.695 740\u00a0</td><td>0.2329\u00a0</td><td>Jullo, PhD thesis\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>A 2667\u00a0</td><td>357.914 125\u00a0</td><td>\u221226.084 375\u00a0</td><td>0.2264\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b18\" data-open=\"b18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Covone et al. (2006)</a>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/64680502\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\"></p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A 773 and A 1835 were included in Sm05's sample, however, in the absence of spectroscopic confirmation, only weak-lensing constraints were used to construct the mass models.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A 521 was studied by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b49\" data-open=\"b49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Maurogordato et al. (2000)</a> using ground-based images. A giant arc feature was observed but spectroscopic follow-up attempts were unable to confirm its strong-lensing origin.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A 773, A 868, A 1835, A 2204 and Z2701 were part of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b67\" data-open=\"b67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sand et al. (2005)</a> sample, who performed a systematic search for radial and tangential arc features in archival <em>HST</em> images of massive clusters. They identified radial arcs in A 773, A 1835 and A 2204.</p></li></ul>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680505 id=\"64680505\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2>2.2 Imaging data</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680506 id=\"64680506\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2-1>2.2.1 HST imaging data</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">High-resolution imaging data taken with the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) or Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 (WFPC2) instrument on <em>HST</em> are available for each selected cluster in one or two bands, either through our dedicated LoCuSS programme (GO-DD 11312, PI: G. P. Smith) or from the archive. These data are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. In every case, one of the observed filters is located between the <em>V</em> and the <em>I</em> band, the most common being the F606W filter.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each <em>HST</em> observation consists of several independent frames arranged in a dither pattern. These images were combined using the <span class=\"small-caps\">multidrizzle</span> software with a final plate scale of 0.05 arcsec (ACS) or 0.1 arcsec (WFPC2). In the case of A 868, the observations comprise a mosaic of six WFPC2 pointings taken at different epochs. This mosaic was combined using the relative astrometric shifts measured from bright objects in common between two adjacent pointings.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A careful visual inspection was performed on the reduced <em>HST</em> images by two of the authors (JR and GPS) to search for strong-lensing features. A catalogue of candidate multiple images was compiled by selecting highly sheared arc-like features, as well as objects displaying a very similar morphology and the characteristic symmetric effect of strong lensing (e.g. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f2\" data-open=\"f2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 2</a>). The majority of these multiple images does not appear like arcs, but have a clumpy morphology, with multiple knots of star formation. These lensed sources are not detected by automatic arc-finding techniques (e.g. <span class=\"small-caps\">arcfinder</span>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b73\" data-open=\"b73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Seidel &amp; Bartelmann 2007</a>), and therefore justify the use of a visual inspection of the images.</p>                        <a id=\"64680510\" scrollto-destination=\"64680510\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f2a.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=zp5JVZ70ILJe4CnzDI3aiqPWhsGTEkiHx6etCnvoQzz5P5NUk3BSaDHt2DXsz-B1hcng1tWZ1QQ-lsQ4DDCifZ99sFZfM88HuRec5UD7RMkLzf0TFzJaoVjJrg4HwcyV-pmwyWPn~0rKcADJJ1nuNXZWEmoiGRRFB2-UapZscenmjY9DvA0E~WCy3PpmHsHq79c2rQgsqa7U18O-APWVqZNq~aoKZfw0L-oPZKHoYWVtrde79EviPmog7~hbeuzAnF2~uxkdtj7tSSobtPes1Uj6rgmesS9DvtmiKbRnYD7PBERA6SLQ4jNgQqnl~PwHKM~DBohKz4TakiiBp-nhYA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multiple-image identifications and critical line at redshift 1.0 (A 521), 0.91 and 2.1 (A 611), 2.3 (A 773), 0.55 (A 868), 1.2 (Z2701) and 1.1 (A 2204). Individual knots used as independent constraints are marked in A 521 and A 611. The critical lines are presented at redshift 2.07 (A 1835, system 7), 2.0 and 2.7 (A 1413), 2.1 (RXJ1720) and 2.0 (RXJ2129).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"f2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f2a.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=zp5JVZ70ILJe4CnzDI3aiqPWhsGTEkiHx6etCnvoQzz5P5NUk3BSaDHt2DXsz-B1hcng1tWZ1QQ-lsQ4DDCifZ99sFZfM88HuRec5UD7RMkLzf0TFzJaoVjJrg4HwcyV-pmwyWPn~0rKcADJJ1nuNXZWEmoiGRRFB2-UapZscenmjY9DvA0E~WCy3PpmHsHq79c2rQgsqa7U18O-APWVqZNq~aoKZfw0L-oPZKHoYWVtrde79EviPmog7~hbeuzAnF2~uxkdtj7tSSobtPes1Uj6rgmesS9DvtmiKbRnYD7PBERA6SLQ4jNgQqnl~PwHKM~DBohKz4TakiiBp-nhYA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multiple-image identifications and critical line at redshift 1.0 (A 521), 0.91 and 2.1 (A 611), 2.3 (A 773), 0.55 (A 868), 1.2 (Z2701) and 1.1 (A 2204). alt=\"Multiple-image identifications and critical line at redshift 1.0 (A 521), 0.91 and 2.1 (A 611), 2.3 (A 773), 0.55 (A 868), 1.2 (Z2701) and 1.1 (A 2204). Individual knots used as independent constraints are marked in A 521 and A 611. The critical lines are presented at redshift 2.07 (A 1835, system 7), 2.0 and 2.7 (A 1413), 2.1 (RXJ1720) and 2.0 (RXJ2129).\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f2b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680510/mnras0404-0325-f2b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f2b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680510\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f2b.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=2Vs-wIzioV0LmJcp0zmfzsU~TRT8u0NBMkvT8Pe9iJBL~CHNyUzdE~fvuYI6jK72UwoITmoPSvbvs8qvpcbyuJP7gUbT9bpxSdKjufwpDh95ZrgzrH14NzJLk~GZUbvKb9Y3rcn4yS5vnkBZEXaEScygZmx6ePTDYnNBcEC7rwztjqLiE5xezBgbL2Lv9t97Lww6JU4OHtxiZLQyRnIfErs2LhezzAZi5ypqnGTiQ52YifJQaxnsFLOXRs-YU07QQo5Vi7c8UaX7eBFeh2gObP1yEL-WqFbANt2y-OxaUTmb1SMSMGYHYd4QnI2tzetl5jP1eJVCToSoKVI5T7HXhw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=64680510&amp;ar=3101555&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f2b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple-image identifications and critical line at redshift 1.0 (A 521), 0.91 and 2.1 (A 611), 2.3 (A 773), 0.55 (A 868), 1.2 (Z2701) and 1.1 (A 2204). Individual knots used as independent constraints are marked in A 521 and A 611. The critical lines are presented at redshift 2.07 (A 1835, system 7), 2.0 and 2.7 (A 1413), 2.1 (RXJ1720) and 2.0 (RXJ2129).</p></div></div>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680511 id=\"64680511\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2-2>2.2.2 Near-infrared imaging data</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>J</em>- and <em>K<sub>S</sub></em>-band data were obtained between 2003 March and 2007 April on the following near-infrared instruments: Wide Infrared Camera (WIRC) on the Palomar-200-inch telescope, Infrared Side Port Imager (ISPI) on the CTIO Blanco 4-m telescope and Florida Infrared Imaging Multi-Object Spectrograph (FLAMINGOS) on the Kitt Peak (KPNO) 4-m telescope. The properties of the data are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. Observations in each filter comprised multiple frames with individual exposure times in the range 30\u2013120 s. These images were combined using standard <span class=\"small-caps\">iraf</span> reduction techniques, full details will be provided in Smith et al. (in preparation), and flux calibrated using the Two Micron All-Sky Survey source catalogue. A dithering box of 80 arcsec width was used in order to improve the photometry of the extended envelope of the brightest cluster Galaxies (BCGs). The field of view of the final dithered images is larger than 8 \u00d7 8 arcmin<sup>2</sup>, centred on the BCG. This entirely covers the central <em>R</em> &lt; 600 kpc of each cluster (as measured from the BCG). We used the SE<span class=\"small-caps\">xtractor</span> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b6\" data-open=\"b6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bertin &amp; Arnouts 1996</a>) software to derive a photometric catalogue of <span class=\"small-caps\">magauto</span> magnitudes in the <em>K<sub>S</sub></em> band, as well as the <em>J</em>\u2212<em>K<sub>S</sub></em> colours inside 4.0-arcsec diameter apertures.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680513 id=\"64680513\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-2-3>2.2.3 Photometric catalogues of cluster galaxies</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to include galaxy-scale components in the strong-lens models (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss3-2\"></span><a href=\"#ss3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 3.2</a>), it is important to perform a systematic selection of cluster members with their geometrical parameters (centroid \u03b1<sub>c</sub>, \u03b4<sub>c</sub>, ellipticity <em>e</em><sub>c</sub> and position angle \u03b8<sub>c</sub>) and total photometry in the <em>K<sub>S</sub></em> band. Indeed, <em>K<sub>S</sub></em> magnitudes are a more accurate proxy for stellar mass when making the assumption that light traces mass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cluster galaxies were selected from the near-infrared catalogue using the red-sequence technique on a <em>J</em>\u2212<em>K<sub>S</sub></em>/<em>K<sub>S</sub></em> colour\u2013magnitude diagram (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b89\" data-open=\"b89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Visvanathan &amp; Sandage 1977</a>). We adopted a liming magnitude of <em>K<sub>S</sub></em>= 20 (<span class=\"small-caps\">magauto</span>) and a colour width of 0.3 mag for the sequence (above three times the photometric uncertainties). The corresponding diagrams and colour selection regions are presented in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>. A final catalogue of cluster members is obtained by correlating the <em>HST</em> and near-infrared photometric catalogues: in the central region, the geometrical parameters (\u03b1<sub>c</sub>, \u03b4<sub>c</sub>, <em>e</em><sub>c</sub>, \u03b8<sub>c</sub>) of cluster members are replaced by their more accurate measurements from the <em>HST</em> image.</p>                        <a id=\"64680516\" scrollto-destination=\"64680516\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"f1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=rYzlQ1ENIUtTvilqLVQmBjvRXsvWcUwz0~SMbHw-8VKF4WkCwwSWtWYDbKwKTb8d1YPoi2ANc56duSEbUluTaLYnC1myv90a4DjBiFPvoyS31w8PQjVbVmG7n5dsEGXwXgIzwUkUTGI8M0Lmtcs~0T9pbwewrTKKQXQbXCZE247zHoXz84mDlKEj4m5vjo4vf~OeT4fe6waJaa30VGT9F3Hu6B7ho8t7YoWtlEDy3ToOssiifroACWXXIQ0L~iwROZrCoVmm7JRWX1-FdlwqUMirnrorocPeZw05WmxdO9sjq8f5mIquWyHQWUjoezCQdOJO3knYe6C5Ha5EdJLktg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"J\u2212KS versus KS colour\u2013magnitude diagrams for each observed cluster, showing the red-sequence selection of cluster members (red dots). The photometric selection used is shown as delimited by the solid box (see the text for details). The last two panels show the red-sequence parameters (intercept at KS= 18 and slope ) as a function of cluster redshift. The solid line gives the expected colours of an elliptical galaxy, and the dashed line marks the average slope  for the sample.\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/64680516/mnras0404-0325-f1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"64680516\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/mnras0404-0325-f1.jpeg?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=tAsUCwbXU627r1QbyxbdBR0mTzjwy9lM5VAH7XTYmNjy-V1vO4uB7GX4p0zveZDmrpGE2CFPcs0n8FobvQbVgylMrD61vmeqBBwyCnLr0vu934TqNdKgcuJ5qupzsjQWuHLI8yVPBT4-q8RiocV70WIuHTTh653m93Wshv6tuaUdV4jqNT9pEuHjhdtpAHOJzoskz1441m-FUYbpEfUe3w~e0l053DRWryjjCUmndUNF22-R8feQ68gZT0dHAxvrACJVKlhjuXb5PUGvGcisCrtXROWOh2HA9oJE0N5cv8UFzzEfUnP1MCR4gsdyKJTWg5WF-VT09~joHbTIS8mV3Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=64680516&amp;ar=3101555&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-f1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>J</em>\u2212<em>K<sub>S</sub></em> versus <em>K<sub>S</sub></em> colour\u2013magnitude diagrams for each observed cluster, showing the red-sequence selection of cluster members (red dots). alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu14.gif\" /></span> for the sample.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As a sanity check, we plot the red-sequence parameters used in our photometric selection (<em>J</em>\u2212<em>K<sub>S</sub></em> colour at fixed <em>K<sub>S</sub></em>-band magnitude and linear slope <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu1.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=oMyB0sbRqS2wv7wAhg0nDP-HBSzkRhzHlafHhFzFAZjztP7iJpNibK~0rAjNokSVxFTznI46GnGuo20xlg-YcxmAHP3IATIq9hkxLzEUVH2KyF8MizkTqzAXDl--kiTgi5Sy6Vp-uUagIRP2Q3ybadIqx9lZE55sGW5SYe4EsQJ8Ps0rvB1vWQlhRWeHjGOc21F1lU0EelISalpYM4heKB4Tl3a9grRZyxjL6B8j3ph2CrUfL1EOurZT~ORJs6ecDDbwp-gczAfuUtfvRVSPu6Mh79PX1qvlzIBjOtAexElFZudhyfNHGos0Bbtliv9grha3KBRQCOVbsf5ajYnD~Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu1.gif\" /></span> of the colour\u2013magnitude diagrams) as a function of the cluster redshift (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f1\" data-open=\"f1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. 1</a>, last two panels). The correlation between <em>J</em>\u2212<em>K<sub>S</sub></em> at <em>K<sub>S</sub></em>= 18 follows the expected colour of elliptical galaxies (using the empirical model from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b17\" data-open=\"b17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Coleman, Wu &amp; Weedman 1980</a>), while the slope <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu2.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=s4PI~ZUAf4CmrSeo5MEF6sUIUiA7ZNcnHnQzrPlisZ5vSM1XJ8ChkQvq8c1vJ46GsXTgEufFDTbbidWcUiMOz1Tx~6JomAP5B35uBkfYDtHvHzIUYWQzN8eALBM6MVVM~OmLBvHQCsUIE7H-2Bfv~ReXf-3ROZ2Pz-ZNJxJDbpT1BMXaVagRk3DMV0iYQ7VzxShuiBe8KuqxUmon0PlszU~iBdKvMVvNdvMmkVLJp2RGsbNPRz~IlYfMlGP3jjXsfm37hsdGXcfn2KfQzywxyw~lNOcSZDaMoOdE~Kbp1AeBSiPzgzLvLvHNgUCYjm5PpEhQNoRGHwNuvzlFceHAhA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu2.gif\" /></span> is scattered around an average value <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\"><img class=\"contentFigures\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/404/1/10.1111_j.1365-2966.2009.16274.x/1/m_mnras0404-0325-mu3.gif?Expires=1639265784&amp;Signature=m4~v2uc4n~gmc53ae46oJoSRf119NDo79UUvcUZhsYIDH51Oyb298ipykbEG0kwxfIdJ1uBE~T5AF3Ykmy4D3f7-GauXXTyqQ039kDUzgWxyTFFOV2h~yR1HS3jL3n88AN-gpWK0MUM03MztTR2-R1s0uZWMdVeU3FdLjAXJ1AkbVp8VKQImdZnFHRAsiPQXyRdudWgw~y6PiI6ldZntvD5Y6H14evlE4r03rwgHgDptbIwKFzy61lPY22E2Jh0SNxJIkKaj3Iz0Vikmkkl2~jBnil1TdOxYOWWG48rEN1McjJmM7~aMzsMJbofVESg5SA7PY9tAXF-v4cYpqQEQtg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"forumla\" data-path-from-xml=\"mnras0404-0325-mu3.gif\" />\u2060</span>, compatible with similar measurements obtained by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b83\" data-open=\"b83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Stott et al. (2009)</a> in this range of cluster redshifts.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We estimated <em>K</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub><em>S</em></sub>, the <em>K<sub>S</sub></em>-band magnitude of an <em>L</em><sup>\u2605</sup> galaxy, following the results from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b45\" data-open=\"b45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Lin et al. (2006)</a>. They show that the evolution of <em>K</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub><em>S</em></sub> with cluster redshift is best reproduced by a single burst model at <em>z</em><sub>form</sub>= 1.5 from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b14\" data-open=\"b14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Bruzual &amp; Charlot (2003)</a>, assuming a Salpeter initial mass function and solar metallicity. Their best-fitting <em>K</em><sup>\u2605</sup><sub><em>S</em></sub>(<em>z</em>) values are reported in the final column of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t1\" data-open=\"t1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 1</a>. Our current selection down to <em>K<sub>S</sub></em>= 20 enables us to select cluster members down to \u223c0.1<em>L</em><sup>\u2605</sup>. Since the fraction of fainter cluster members not included in our selection contribute to less than 1 per cent of the total <em>K</em>-band luminosity, this selection does not affect our results on the <em>K</em>-band properties in the entire sample.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680519 id=\"64680519\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-3>2.3 Spectroscopic data</h3>\r\n                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680520 id=\"64680520\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-3-1>2.3.1 Observing strategy</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We used the LRIS (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b58\" data-open=\"b58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Oke et al. 1995</a>) on the Keck-I telescope to perform long-slit and multislit observations of the clusters. The spectroscopic data used in the current paper are the outcome of six different observing runs between 2004 and 2008, which are summarized in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680522\" scrollto-destination=\"64680522\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t3\" class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/64680522\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We designed multislit masks containing \u223c30 slits of 1.0 arcsec width to include as many of the candidate multiple systems as possible, with a few tilted slits following the geometry of long arcs. In the case of fainter or less reliable identifications, several images of the same system were observed in separate slits. Additional slits in the mask included faint galaxies with unknown redshifts, bright infrared sources selected at 24 \u03bcm or cluster members.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The dichroic/grism/grating combinations are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a> to ensure a high throughput over the wavelength range 3500\u20139500 \u00c5 and good spectral resolution (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t3\" data-open=\"t3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 3</a>) in the red to resolve OH skylines as well as [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] emission line doublets in the redshift range 0.85\u20131.50. The total exposure time varied between 1 and 3 h per mask, depending on the seeing conditions and the detection of strong emission lines when looking over a first reduction of the data at the telescope.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=64680525 id=\"64680525\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-3-2>2.3.2 Data reduction</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The data were reduced using the <span class=\"small-caps\">python</span> version of the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b36\" data-open=\"b36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Kelson (2003)</a> reduction scripts, which offer the advantage of processing the images in their distorted framework. This helps to reduce noise correlations, in particular for the case of tilted slits. We performed standard reduction steps for bias removal, flat-field correction, wavelength calibration, sky subtraction and cosmic-ray rejection, and used observations of spectroscopic standard stars obtained on the same nights to derive the flux calibration.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The extracted spectra of objects used in the present paper are shown in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-f14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"f14\" data-open=\"f14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Fig. A1</a> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss9\"></span><a href=\"#ss9\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Appendix A</a>). These spectra show Lyman \u03b1 (Ly\u03b1 in absorption or emission) and/or additional ultraviolet (UV) absorption lines, or the resolved [O <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet. For some faint multiple systems observed in different slits, redshift measurements were derived after stacking the relevant exposures. The average redshift value is obtained from the peaks of the main spectral features identified, while the corresponding error is taken from the spectral dispersion. Additional uncertainties generated by the accuracy of the relative and absolute wavelength calibrations, about 1.1 and 1.5 \u00c5, respectively, were quadratically added to yield the final redshift errors. The redshifts are listed in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t4\" data-open=\"t4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680528\" scrollto-destination=\"64680528\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t4\" data-id=\"t4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Properties of the multiple-image systems. Redshift values quoted with brackets are predictions from the lensing model. The last two columns give the observed <em>HST</em> magnitudes and linear magnification factor predicted by the lens model.</p></div> </div><div 722\u00a0</td><td>1.965 \u00b1 0.005\u00a0</td><td>Si <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>, Si <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>, C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>\u00a0</td><td>23.05 \u00b1 0.02\u00a0</td><td>2.33 \u00b1 0.25\u00a0</td><td>8.6 \u00b1 2.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>1.3\u00a0</td><td>322.417 98\u00a0</td><td>0.093 250\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>24.74 \u00b1 class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> Location of the brightest knot in the image. <sup><em>b</em></sup>Photometry is the sum of 1.1 and 1.2 images.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-t4_note681\"></span><div content-id=\"t4_note681\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>a</em></sup> Dannerbauer et al. (in preparation). <sup><em>b</em></sup>See also <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b90\" data-open=\"b90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Wilman et al. (2006)</a>. <sup><em>c</em></sup>Photometry is the sum of 1.1 and 1.2 images.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/64680528\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=64680529 id=\"64680529\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=ss2-4>2.4 X-ray observations</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">X-ray properties of the LoCuSS clusters have been determined for 18/20 clusters from <em>Chandra</em> archival observations, which were reduced and analysed as described in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson, Edge &amp; Smith (2009a)</a> following the methods developed by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b68\" data-open=\"b68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson &amp; Ponman (2010)</a>. Annular gas temperature and density profiles were derived and fitted with the phenomenological cluster model of <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b3\" data-open=\"b3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Ascasibar &amp; Diego (2008)</a>, to determine the total cluster mass profile. These models are based on the <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b32\" data-open=\"b32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Hernquist (1990)</a> profile, which has the advantage of yielding convergent three- and two-dimensional mass measurements. The latter is particularly helpful when comparing lensing and X-ray based measurements of the projected mass within <em>R</em> &lt; 250 kpc (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-ss2-4\"></span><a href=\"#ss2-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">Section 2.4</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The X-ray models were also used to measure the gradient of the logarithmic gas density profile at 0.04<em>r</em><sub>500</sub> (\u03b1; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vikhlinin et al. 2007</a>), which quantifies the strength of cooling in the core (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vikhlinin et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. 2009a</a>). Core-excluded mean temperatures for the clusters were also measured in the range 0.15\u22120.2<em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, according to the procedure outlined in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. (2009b)</a>. We classify clusters as hosting a cool core if the slope of the gas density profile is \u03b1 &lt; \u22120.85. This matches the range of \u03b1 displayed by clusters that contain an H\u03b1 emitting BCG in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. (2009a)</a>. Under this definition, 8/18 clusters as cool-core clusters, corresponding to 44 \u00b1 14 per cent where the error bar is a binomial uncertainty following <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b27\" data-open=\"b27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Gehrels (1986)</a>. We also classify clusters as \u2018disturbed\u2019 if the offset between the X-ray centroid and the BCG is &gt;0.01<em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, this identifies all except three of the clusters containing an H\u03b1 emitting BCG in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al.</a> (2009a, see their fig. 5). This yields a fraction of 67<sup>+12</sup><sub>\u221215</sub> per cent of the sample that are classified as undisturbed. All cool-core clusters are also classified as undisturbed, however four non-cool-core clusters are also classified as undisturbed. The resulting X-ray properties are given in <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-t5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"t5\" data-open=\"t5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">Table 5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"64680532\" scrollto-destination=\"64680532\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"t5\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"t5\" data-id=\"t5\"><span class=\"label\">Table 5</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of <em>Chandra</em> X-ray properties for the Keck sample (first half) and the extended sample (second half).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Cluster<span 0.1\u20132.4 keV band from <em>ROSAT</em> (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b19\" data-open=\"b19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal 2004</a>). <sup><em>b</em></sup><em>Chandra</em> observation identifier. <sup><em>c</em></sup>Measured between 0.15 and 0.2<em>r</em><sub>500</sub> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b70\" data-open=\"b70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. 2009b</a>). <sup><em>d</em></sup>Logarithmic slope of the gas density profile at 0.04<em>r</em><sub>500</sub> (see <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b88\" data-open=\"b88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Vikhlinin et al. 2007</a>; <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b68\" data-open=\"b68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson &amp; Ponman 2010</a>). <sup><em>e</em></sup>X-ray centroid/BCG offset from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-b69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"b69\" data-open=\"b69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">Sanderson et al. (2009a)</a>. Errors are 1\u03c3.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\"
